\\sqrt{\\dfrac{5}{13}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D%7D%3B+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B2%7D%7B5%7D%7D%3B+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B8%7D%7D%3B+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B5%7D%7B13%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

It is apparent that these sequences are constructed from consecutive or
every second term of the mātrā-meru-paṅkti.

**Map 2**  
![x\_{n+1}=\\cos\\left(\\arctan\\left( y_n\\right) \\right); \\;
y_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Ccos%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28+y_n%5Cright%29+%5Cright%29%3B+%5C%3B+y_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![y\_{n+1}=\\sin\\left(\\arctan\\left(
x\_{n+1}\\right)\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Csin%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28+x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%5Cright%29%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Here, as ![n \\to \\infty\\;\\; x\_{n} \\to \\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt\[4\]{2}},
\\; y\_{n} \\to
\\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{1+\\sqrt{2}}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%5C%3B%5C%3B+x_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%5B4%5D%7B2%7D%7D%2C+%5C%3B+y_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B1%2B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We see that ![x_n \\rightarrow \\sqrt{\\dfrac{1}{2}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{3}{4}}, \\sqrt{\\dfrac{7}{10}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{17}{24}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B7%7D%7B10%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B17%7D%7B24%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This sequence can be derived from the sequence ![\\textbf{1, 2, 3, 4, 7,
10, 17,
24...}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextbf%7B1%2C+2%2C+3%2C+4%2C+7%2C+10%2C+17%2C+24...%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which has ![f\[1\]=1,
f\[2\]=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B1%5D%3D1%2C+f%5B2%5D%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and alternating terms of the form ![f\[n+1\]=f\[n\]+f\[n-1\],
f\[n+1\]=f\[n\]+f\[n-2\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%2B1%5D%3Df%5Bn%5D%2Bf%5Bn-1%5D%2C+f%5Bn%2B1%5D%3Df%5Bn%5D%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Further, we have ![y_n \\rightarrow \\sqrt{\\dfrac{1}{3}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{3}{7}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{7}{17}}....](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B7%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B7%7D%7B17%7D%7D....&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

One notices that it is constructed from the above integer sequence by
taking the square root of the ratio of ever second term.

**Map 3**  
![x\_{n+1}=\\cos\\left(\\arctan\\left(y_n\\right) \\right); \\;
y_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Ccos%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28y_n%5Cright%29+%5Cright%29%3B+%5C%3B+y_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![y\_{n+1}=\\sin\\left(\\arctan\\left(\\frac{x\_{n+1}}{y_n}\\right)\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Csin%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cfrac%7Bx_%7Bn%2B1%7D%7D%7By_n%7D%5Cright%29%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Here, as ![n \\to \\infty\\;\\; x\_{n} \\to
\\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt\[6\]{2\\tau}}, \\; y\_{n} \\to
\\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{\\tau}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%5C%3B%5C%3B+x_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%5B6%5D%7B2%5Ctau%7D%7D%2C+%5C%3B+y_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B%5Ctau%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

where
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the convergent of [Nārāyaṇa’s
sāmāsika-paṅkti](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2019/07/26/naraya%e1%b9%87as-sequence-madhavas-series-and-pi/)
(known in the Occident as the tribonacci constant)

We see that ![x_n \\rightarrow 1, \\sqrt{\\dfrac{1}{2}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{3}{4}}, \\sqrt{\\dfrac{13}{22}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{367}{536}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{225273}{359962}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n+%5Crightarrow+1%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B13%7D%7B22%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B367%7D%7B536%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B225273%7D%7B359962%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This sequence defines an oscillatory convergence to
![\\tfrac{1}{\\sqrt\[6\]{2\\tau}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%5B6%5D%7B2%5Ctau%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and can be derived from integer sequence: ![\\textbf{1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 4,
13, 22, 367, 536, 225273,
359962...}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextbf%7B1%2C+1%2C+1%2C+2%2C+3%2C+4%2C+13%2C+22%2C+367%2C+536%2C+225273%2C+359962...%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Here, ![f\[1\]= 1, f\[2\]=1,
f\[3\]=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B1%5D%3D+1%2C+f%5B2%5D%3D1%2C+f%5B3%5D%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and every alternate term is defined by the formulae:

![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\] +
f\[n-3\]^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D+%2B+f%5Bn-3%5D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\] \\cdot
f\[n-2\]+f\[n-4\]^4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D+%5Ccdot+f%5Bn-2%5D%2Bf%5Bn-4%5D%5E4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Further, we see that ![y_n \\rightarrow \\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{3}},
\\dfrac{3}{\\sqrt{13}},
\\dfrac{13}{\\sqrt{367}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B13%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B13%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B367%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This sequence can again be derived from the above integer sequence by
taking every other term, 1, 3, 13, 367 and results in an oscillatory
convergence to
![\\tfrac{1}{\\sqrt{\\tau}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B%5Ctau%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

**Map 4**  
![x\_{n+1}=\\cos\\left(\\arctan\\left(x_n^2\\right) \\right); \\;
x_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Ccos%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28x_n%5E2%5Cright%29+%5Cright%29%3B+%5C%3B+x_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![y\_{n+1}=\\sin\\left(\\arctan\\left(x\_{n+1}^2\\right)\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Csin%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%5E2%5Cright%29%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

To understand the convergent of this map consider the unit circle
![x^2+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and the cubic parabola
![y=x^3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3Dx%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 2).

*[![cubic_circle_inter](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/cubic_circle_inter.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/cubic_circle_inter.png)Figure
2*

Here,
![\\lambda_1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the positive intersect of the two curves with coordinates
![(\\lambda_x,
\\lambda_y)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_x%2C+%5Clambda_y%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Further,
![r=\\tfrac{\\lambda_y}{\\lambda_x}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=r%3D%5Ctfrac%7B%5Clambda_y%7D%7B%5Clambda_x%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the only real root of the cubic equation
![x^3+x-1=0](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E3%2Bx-1%3D0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, ![\\lambda_x=\\cos(\\arctan(r)),
\\lambda_y=\\sin(\\arctan(r))](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_x%3D%5Ccos%28%5Carctan%28r%29%29%2C+%5Clambda_y%3D%5Csin%28%5Carctan%28r%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Then, as ![n \\to \\infty\\;\\; x\_{n} \\to \\lambda_x, \\; y\_{n} \\to
\\lambda_y](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%5C%3B%5C%3B+x_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Clambda_x%2C+%5C%3B+y_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Clambda_y&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We see that ![x_n \\rightarrow 1, \\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{2}},
\\dfrac{2}{\\sqrt{5}}, \\dfrac{5}{\\sqrt{41}},
\\dfrac{41}{\\sqrt{2306}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n+%5Crightarrow+1%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B2%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B5%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B5%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B41%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B41%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2306%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

and ![y_n \\rightarrow \\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{5}}, \\dfrac{4}{\\sqrt{41}},
\\dfrac{25}{\\sqrt{2306}},
\\dfrac{1681}{\\sqrt{8143397}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B5%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B4%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B41%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B25%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2306%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B1681%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B8143397%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

These sequences are related to the integer sequence: ![\\textbf{1, 2, 5,
41, 2306,
8143397...}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextbf%7B1%2C+2%2C+5%2C+41%2C+2306%2C+8143397...%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which can be described by the formula:
![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]^2+f\[n-2\]^4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%5E2%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D%5E4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
with ![f\[1\]=1,
f\[2\]=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B1%5D%3D1%2C+f%5B2%5D%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Then
![x_n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is derived from successive terms with the square root of the large term.
![y_n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is derived similarly from every other term with the square of the first
and the square root of the next.

**Map 5**

![x\_{n+1}=\\cos\\left(\\arctan\\left( \\frac{y_n}{x_n}\\right)
\\right); \\; x_0=1,
y_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Ccos%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28+%5Cfrac%7By_n%7D%7Bx_n%7D%5Cright%29+%5Cright%29%3B+%5C%3B+x_0%3D1%2C+y_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![y\_{n+1}=\\sin\\left(\\arctan\\left(
\\frac{x\_{n+1}}{y_n}\\right)\\right); \\;
y_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_%7Bn%2B1%7D%3D%5Csin%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28+%5Cfrac%7Bx_%7Bn%2B1%7D%7D%7By_n%7D%5Cright%29%5Cright%29%3B+%5C%3B+y_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Here, as ![n \\to \\infty\\;\\; x\_{n}, \\; y\_{n} \\to
\\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%5C%3B%5C%3B+x_%7Bn%7D%2C+%5C%3B+y_%7Bn%7D+%5Cto+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

The
![x_n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is interesting in that it begins with
![\\tfrac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and converges back to it in an oscillatory fashion. This convergence
takes the form:

![x_n \\rightarrow \\dfrac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}, \\dfrac{2}{\\sqrt{7}},
\\dfrac{7}{\\sqrt{101}}, \\dfrac{101}{\\sqrt{19609}},
\\dfrac{19609}{\\sqrt{782362082}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_n+%5Crightarrow+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B2%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B7%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B7%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B101%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B101%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B19609%7D%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7B19609%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B782362082%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

The convergence of
![y_n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to
![\\tfrac{1}{\\sqrt{2}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
takes the form:

![y_n \\rightarrow 1, \\sqrt{\\dfrac{2}{3}}, \\sqrt{\\dfrac{7}{13}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{101}{192}},
\\sqrt{\\dfrac{19609}{39001}}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_n+%5Crightarrow+1%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B2%7D%7B3%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B7%7D%7B13%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B101%7D%7B192%7D%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Cdfrac%7B19609%7D%7B39001%7D%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

These sequences can be derived from the integer sequence ![\\textbf{1,
1, 2 ,3, 7, 13, 101, 192, 19609,
39001...}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextbf%7B1%2C+1%2C+2+%2C3%2C+7%2C+13%2C+101%2C+192%2C+19609%2C+39001...%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Given ![f\[1\]=1, f\[2\]=1,
f\[3\]=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B1%5D%3D1%2C+f%5B2%5D%3D1%2C+f%5B3%5D%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
the subsequent alternate terms of this sequence are defined the formulae

![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]+f\[n-2\] \\cdot
f\[n-3\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D+%5Ccdot+f%5Bn-3%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![f\[n\]=f\[n-2\]^2+f\[n-1\] \\cdot
f\[n-4\]^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-2%5D%5E2%2Bf%5Bn-1%5D+%5Ccdot+f%5Bn-4%5D%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

More generally the convergents obtained for any of the above maps will
be reached from any other starting
![(x_0,y_0)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x_0%2Cy_0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
but using
![x_0=y_0=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_0%3Dy_0%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
gives us a convergence via easy to understand explicit sequences.

**Rational points on a unit circle**  
There are some events that happen in the course of ones life that might
be considered historical or world-changing. One such event from our
lifetime is the proving of the Last Theorem of Fermat (FLT). While the
proof of the FLT is inaccessible to persons with meager mathematical
understanding like us, its algebraic form can be understood by anyone
with a very limited knowledge of mathematics. Its geometric form is
deeply linked to a basic aspect of Euclidean space, and it was this form
that amazed us as a kid. This can be presented as a very simple problem:
given the curve ![x^n+y^n=1; \\; n=1, 2,
3,...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5En%2By%5En%3D1%3B+%5C%3B+n%3D1%2C+2%2C+3%2C...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 1), are there rational points that lie on the curve? A rational
point is a point
![(x,y)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where both
![x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![y](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are rational numbers.

[![Fermat_LT_curves](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/fermat_lt_curves.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/fermat_lt_curves.png)Figure
1

These curves may be divided two topologically distinct groups based on
the parity of the exponent
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
If ![n=2k+1; k=0, 1,
2...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D2k%2B1%3B+k%3D0%2C+1%2C+2...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then the curve is bilaterally symmetric about
![y=x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3Dx&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and cuts the x-axis and the y-axis once at
![(1,0)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![(0,1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
respectively (Figure 1). If instead ![n=2k+2; k=0, 1,
2...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D2k%2B2%3B+k%3D0%2C+1%2C+2...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then the curve is closed, symmetric about both axes and the lines ![y =
\\pm
x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y+%3D+%5Cpm+x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
and cuts the the x-axis and the y-axis twice at ![(\\pm 1,
0)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Cpm+1%2C+0%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and ![(0, \\pm
1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C+%5Cpm+1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
respectively (Figure 1). It is easy to see that the case where
![n=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
has infinite rational points. The case for
![n=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
defines a circle and that too has infinite rational points on it (see
below). Remarkably, the FLT states that there are no rational points for
any of the curves with ![n \\ge
3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n+%5Cge+3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
other than of course the trivial points where the curve cuts the axes.
This is a rather profound statement regarding the geometry of Euclidean
space as it means that, other than the line
![x+y=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%2By%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and the unit circle, none of other members of this family of unit curves
can ever pass through non-trivial rational points.

Now, what are the rational points on a circle? These are linked to the
defining theorem of Euclidean space — the theorem of the right triangle
or the bhujā-koṭi-karṇa-nyāya: we have for a right triangle with the
three sides ![a, b,
c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%2C+b%2C+c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
in order of length,  
![a^2+b^2=c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bb%5E2%3Dc%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Dividing the equation by
![c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we get:  
![\\dfrac{a^2}{c^2}+\\dfrac{b^2}{c^2}=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7Ba%5E2%7D%7Bc%5E2%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7Bb%5E2%7D%7Bc%5E2%7D%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Writing
![\\tfrac{a}{c}=x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Ba%7D%7Bc%7D%3Dx&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![\\tfrac{b}{c}=y](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bb%7D%7Bc%7D%3Dy&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we get the equation of the unit circle:  
![x^2+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Therefore, the primitive right-triangle triples
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(because they are
![90^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles), where
![\\textrm{GCD}(a,b,c)=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%28a%2Cb%2Cc%29%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
define the rational points on a unit circle of the form ![\\left(
\\tfrac{a}{c},
\\tfrac{b}{c}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cleft%28+%5Ctfrac%7Ba%7D%7Bc%7D%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bb%7D%7Bc%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
It has been known since antiquity that the right triangle triples have a
deep connection to the greatest common divisor of two numbers. Thus,
given two positive integers ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
if
![\\textrm{GCD}(u,v)=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%28u%2Cv%29%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![v>u](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v%3Eu&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we can generate triples using the below formulae (something one learns
by secondary school):

![x=v^2-u^2\\\\\[6pt\] y=2uv\\\\\[6pt\]
z=u^2+v^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3Dv%5E2-u%5E2%5C%5C%5B6pt%5D+y%3D2uv%5C%5C%5B6pt%5D+z%3Du%5E2%2Bv%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

For example, ![u=1,
v=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D1%2C+v%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
yield ![3, 4,
5](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=3%2C+4%2C+5&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
the most primitive of all
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. It figures in many ancient holy objects like the Śrīcakra or in
the layout of the city of Ayodhyā. However, if both ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are odd then
![v^2-u^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v%5E2-u%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
![2uv](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2uv&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![u^2+v^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%5E2%2Bv%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will all be even. Hence, they cannot constitute a primitive
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple: e.g. ![u=1,
v=3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D1%2C+v%3D3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will yield ![6, 8,
10](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6%2C+8%2C+10&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is simply the ![3, 4,
5](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=3%2C+4%2C+5&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle magnified 2 times. Thus, we need an additional condition so
that we consider only those triples generated by the above formulae
which themselves have ![\\textrm{GCD}(v^2-u^2, 2uv,
u^2+v^2)=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%28v%5E2-u%5E2%2C+2uv%2C+u%5E2%2Bv%5E2%29%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, we eliminate all ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
sharing an odd parity. Given that the above procedure ensures that
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will be positive, if we further ensure that the sides are arranged by
increasing order of length then the minimal set of primitive triples,
![a, b,
c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%2C+b%2C+c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
will necessarily occupy only the octant of a circle between
![\\left\[\\tfrac{\\pi}{4},\\tfrac{\\pi}{2}\\right\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cleft%5B%5Ctfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B4%7D%2C%5Ctfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B2%7D%5Cright%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 2). This set of primitive triples
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
can then be used to get rational points on the entire perimeter of the
circle by placing
![b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
before
![a](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and changing their signs one at a time.  
[![triples_bbk_below10000](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_bbk_below10000.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_bbk_below10000.png)

Figure 2. ![T\_{90} \\le
10000](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D+%5Cle+10000&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

The above procedure shows that there are infinite
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples (Figure 2 shows those with ![c \\le
10000](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c+%5Cle+10000&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002))
and thus there are infinite rational points that lie on a unit circle.
However, for the past 80 or so years it has been known that there is a
hierarchy to the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples with the ![T^0\_{90}=(3, 4,
5)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%5E0_%7B90%7D%3D%283%2C+4%2C+5%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple being the mother of all of them. We represent it as the below
matrix:

![T^0\_{90}=\\begin{bmatrix} 3\\\\ 4\\\\ 5\\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%5E0_%7B90%7D%3D%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+3%5C%5C+4%5C%5C+5%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We then define 3 transformation matrices:

![M_1= \\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 2 \\\\ 2 & 1 & 2 \\\\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_1%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+1+%26+2+%26+2+%5C%5C+2+%26+1+%26+2+%5C%5C+2+%26+2+%26+3+%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![M_2= \\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2 & 2 \\\\ 2 & -1 & 2 \\\\ 2 & -2 & 3 \\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_2%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+1+%26+-2+%26+2+%5C%5C+2+%26+-1+%26+2+%5C%5C+2+%26+-2+%26+3+%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![M_3= \\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 2 & 2 \\\\ -2 & 1 & 2 \\\\ -2 & 2 & 3 \\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_3%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+-1+%26+2+%26+2+%5C%5C+-2+%26+1+%26+2+%5C%5C+-2+%26+2+%26+3+%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Then we get three further generation-1 triples from
![\\mathbf{T^{0}\_{90}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BT%5E%7B0%7D_%7B90%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
thus:

![\\mathbf{T^{1.1}\_{90}=M_1 \\cdot T^0\_{90}; \\; T^{1.2}\_{90}=M_2
\\cdot T^0\_{90}; \\; T^{1.3}\_{90}=M_3 \\cdot
T^0\_{90}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BT%5E%7B1.1%7D_%7B90%7D%3DM_1+%5Ccdot+T%5E0_%7B90%7D%3B+%5C%3B+T%5E%7B1.2%7D_%7B90%7D%3DM_2+%5Ccdot+T%5E0_%7B90%7D%3B+%5C%3B+T%5E%7B1.3%7D_%7B90%7D%3DM_3+%5Ccdot+T%5E0_%7B90%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

These ![(20, 21, 29); (5, 12, 13); (8, 15,
17)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%2820%2C+21%2C+29%29%3B+%285%2C+12%2C+13%29%3B+%288%2C+15%2C+17%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
represent the next level in the hierarchy of primitive triples. From
those 3 we get a further generations of 9 and then 27 and so on by
multiplying each triple of the previous generation by each of the
transformation matrices. What serial multiplication by
![\\mathbf{M_1}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM_1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
does is to create right triangles approaching the half-square or
![\\tfrac{\\pi}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
or
![45^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=45%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle. Thus, in the lineage of multiplication by
![M_1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we get triangles such that

![\\textrm{AM}\\left( \\dfrac{c}{a}, \\dfrac{c}{b} \\right)
\\to\\sqrt{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BAM%7D%5Cleft%28+%5Cdfrac%7Bc%7D%7Ba%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7Bc%7D%7Bb%7D+%5Cright%29+%5Cto%5Csqrt%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

For example, ![(119, 120,
169)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28119%2C+120%2C+169%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the 2nd generation triple in the
![\\mathbf{M_1}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM_1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
lineage yields ![\\textrm{AM}\\left( \\tfrac{169}{119},
\\tfrac{169}{120} \\right) =
1.414251](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BAM%7D%5Cleft%28+%5Ctfrac%7B169%7D%7B119%7D%2C+%5Ctfrac%7B169%7D%7B120%7D+%5Cright%29+%3D+1.414251&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which approximates
![\\sqrt{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
correctly to 4 decimal places. In contrast, the matrices
![\\mathbf{M_2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM_2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![\\mathbf{M_3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM_3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
drive the triangles towards the state where one of the sides and the
hypotenuse are nearly equal. When we plot the rational points generated
by the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples on the unit circle we get a fractal structure covering the
primary octant of the said circle (Figure 3).  
[![triples_bbk_on_circ](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_bbk_on_circ.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_bbk_on_circ.png)Figure
3. Rational points on the unit circle derived from
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples with those derived from the primordial triple ![(3, 4,
5)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%283%2C+4%2C+5%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and 3 subsequent generations of triples indicated by disks of decreasing
size.

This structure is characterized by “zones of exclusion” defined by the
high-ranked triples. The biggest such zone is defined by the primordial
![(3, 4,
5)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%283%2C+4%2C+5%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple, followed by those of generation-1 and so on (Figure 3). However,
if one zooms in on the smaller zones of exclusion one sees a fractal
structure mirroring the larger zones.

If we order the triples by the ascending value of
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then we get a remarkable relationship for the count of triples with
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
below or equal to a certain number
![N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):

![\\dfrac{\\#(a, b, c \\le N)}{N} \\simeq
\\dfrac{1}{2\\pi}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%7D%7BN%7D+%5Csimeq+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%5Cpi%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This famous result of the senior Derrick Lehmer, which can be easily
numerically visualized (Figure 4), has links to Leonhard Euler’s
discovery of the
![\\zeta](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Czeta&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
function.

[![triples90_pi](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples90_pi.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples90_pi.png)Figure
4. ![\\tfrac{1}{2 \\pi} \\approx
0.159154943091](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B2+%5Cpi%7D+%5Capprox+0.159154943091&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Its formal proof is complicated (for the mathematical layman) and yields
an additional logarithmic term. However, the basic concept leading to to
Lehmer’s asymptotic result is readily understood. Euler had famously
shown that the probability of two randomly chosen positive integers ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
having
![\\textrm{GCD}(u,v)=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%28u%2Cv%29%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
i.e. being mutually prime, is
![\\tfrac{1}{\\zeta(2)}=\\tfrac{6}{\\pi^2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Czeta%282%29%7D%3D%5Ctfrac%7B6%7D%7B%5Cpi%5E2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
In the above formula for obtaining
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples we start with two mutually prime integers ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, the probability of getting two such mutually prime integers is
defined by this formula of Euler. The hypotenuse
![c=u^2+v^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3Du%5E2%2Bv%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
hence, we can see the points defined by ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for all ![c \\le
N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c+%5Cle+N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
lying inside or on a circle with radius
![\\sqrt{N}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7BN%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and area ![\\pi
N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
However, we do not consider the entire circle; as we saw above, because
of the ordering and sign considerations we only account for one octant
of a circle, i.e.
![\\tfrac{1}{8}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B8%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of its total area. Hence, we get the number of points defined by the
mutually prime ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
such that ![u^2+v^2 \\le
N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%5E2%2Bv%5E2+%5Cle+N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to be ![\\tfrac{6}{\\pi^2} \\cdot \\pi N \\cdot \\tfrac{1}{8} =
\\tfrac{3}{4
\\pi}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B6%7D%7B%5Cpi%5E2%7D+%5Ccdot+%5Cpi+N+%5Ccdot+%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B8%7D+%3D+%5Ctfrac%7B3%7D%7B4+%5Cpi%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
However, not all these points correspond to valid triples. As we saw
above, we have to exclude triples emerging from mutually prime ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which are both odd. This approximately eliminates
![\\tfrac{1}{3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the possible mutually prime couplings (e.g. for 1, 2, 3, we have 1, 2
and 2, 3 as valid couplings but 1,3 is not). Therefore, we have multiply
the value ![\\tfrac{3}{4
\\pi}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B3%7D%7B4+%5Cpi%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
by a correction factor of
![\\tfrac{2}{3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B2%7D%7B3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
leading to the above asymptotic formula of Lehmer.

**![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![60^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles and the rational points on ![\\sqrt{2},
\\sqrt{\\tfrac{2}{3}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7B2%7D%2C+%5Csqrt%7B%5Ctfrac%7B2%7D%7B3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
ellipses**  
Our exploration of this special class of rational points on an ellipse
and its links to integer triangles began in our youth when we added an
important lesson to our very rudimentary knowledge of trigonometry. It
stemmed from a simple question that anyone with limited amount of
geometric knowledge can ask: Are there any other triangles with an angle
defined by a rational sector of a circle (i.e. the angle is rational in
degrees) that have a regular formula (like the right triangle) relating
their sides? In course of our compass and ruler constructions on paper,
we stumbled across the ![(3, 5,
7)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%283%2C+5%2C+7%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple which defines a
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle (Figure 5).

[![120deg_Triangle](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120deg_triangle.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120deg_triangle.png)  
Figure 5. ![(3, 5,
7)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%283%2C+5%2C+7%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
defines a
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle with sides obeying the formula
![a^2+ab+b^2=c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bab%2Bb%5E2%3Dc%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Since at that point we knew of the properties of the famous Platonic
![30^{\\circ}-60^{\\circ}-90^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=30%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D-60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D-90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle, we were able to prove using the bhujā-koṭi-karṇa-nyāya that if
a triangle’s sides are 3, 5, 7 then indeed it has an angle of
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
While doing so it struck us that ![7^2=3^2+5^2+3 \\times
5](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=7%5E2%3D3%5E2%2B5%5E2%2B3+%5Ctimes+5&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and we were able to visualize the same geometrically (Figure 5). We then
became curious if we could find other integer
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles to see if this relationship held. Having drawn a
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
angle on paper, using a sliding ruler we soon obtained another
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle defined by the triple ![7, 8,
13](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=7%2C+8%2C+13&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and found that here again ![7^2+8^2+7 \\times
8=13^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=7%5E2%2B8%5E2%2B7+%5Ctimes+8%3D13%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This sparked our curiosity and we looked up one of our father’s
mathematics books to see if this was recorded. While we did not find it
there, we learned of the generalization of the bhujā-koṭi-karṇa-nyāya,
the cosine rule,
![a^2+b^2-ab\\cos(C)=c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bb%5E2-ab%5Ccos%28C%29%3Dc%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We were able to grasp its implications right away because our father had
introduced us to the trigonometric functions early in life. Thus, it
became clear that
![a^2+b^2+ab=c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bb%5E2%2Bab%3Dc%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
was indeed a property of
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles stemming directly from the cosine rule given that
![\\cos(120^{\\circ})=-\\tfrac{1}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ccos%28120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%29%3D-%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

Further, this implied that we can have such regular formulae only for
one other rational sector triangle, i.e. the
![60^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle. Only the rational sectors corresponding to ![0^{\\circ},
60^{\\circ}, 90^{\\circ}, 120^{\\circ},
180^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=0%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+180%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
have rational cosines. Of these only ![60^{\\circ}, 90^{\\circ},
120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D%2C+120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
can form non-degenerate triangles. These correspond to the formulae:

![\\begin{aligned} 60^{\\circ} &\\rightarrow& a^2+b^2&-ab&=c^2\\\\
90^{\\circ} &\\rightarrow& a^2+b^2& &=c^2\\\\ 120^{\\circ}
&\\rightarrow& a^2+b^2&+ab&=c^2
\\end{aligned}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Baligned%7D+60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D+%26%5Crightarrow%26+a%5E2%2Bb%5E2%26-ab%26%3Dc%5E2%5C%5C+90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D+%26%5Crightarrow%26+a%5E2%2Bb%5E2%26+%26%3Dc%5E2%5C%5C+120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D+%26%5Crightarrow%26+a%5E2%2Bb%5E2%26%2Bab%26%3Dc%5E2+%5Cend%7Baligned%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

While for the
![90^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=90%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and the
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
case the additive formulae imply that that the side
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the largest side, the negative term in the
![60^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
case implies that
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the middle length side of the triangle.

[![120_deg_cube_rel](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120_deg_cube_rel.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120_deg_cube_rel.png)Figure
6. Difference of cubes relationship for a
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle

While the FLT shows that there can be no relationship between 3 rational
cubes like for squares, the
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and the
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
provide a 3-dimensional relationship to the difference and summation of
volumes of cubes and a square-faced cuboid.

![b^3-a^3=(b-a)c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b%5E3-a%5E3%3D%28b-a%29c%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Thus, the difference of the volumes of 2 cubes with edges equal to each
of the two short sides of a
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle ![(a,
b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2C+b%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is equal to a cuboid with a base equal to a square erected on the long
side of the said triangle
![(c)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28c%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and height equal to the difference of the other two sides
![(a-b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a-b%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

![a^3+b^3=(a+b)c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E3%2Bb%5E3%3D%28a%2Bb%29c%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Thus, the sum of the volumes of 2 cubes with edges respectively equal to
the shortest and longest sides of a
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle ![(a,
b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2C+b%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is equal to a cuboid with a base equal to a square erected on the middle
side of the said triangle
![(c)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28c%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and height equal to the sum of the other two sides
![(a+b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2Bb%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

Further, we observed that by dividing the above equations by
![c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and writing ![x=\\tfrac{a}{c}; y=
\\tfrac{b}{c}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D%5Ctfrac%7Ba%7D%7Bc%7D%3B+y%3D+%5Ctfrac%7Bb%7D%7Bc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we get equations of the ellipses
![x^2+xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to the
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle and
![x^2-xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2-xy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to the
![60^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle (Figure 7).

[![rational_points_ellipse](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/rational_points_ellipse.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/rational_points_ellipse.png)Figure
7. The ellipses defined by the rational triangle triples

The above implies that the primitive integer triples corresponding to
the
![120^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle,
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
define rational points that lie on the ellipse
![x^2+xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and those corresponding to the
![60^{\\circ}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%7B%5Ccirc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples,
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
define the rational points on the ellipse
![x^2-xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2-xy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 7). These are special ellipses whose eccentricity and semi-minor
axis are equal to the same value,
![\\sqrt{\\tfrac{2}{3}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7B%5Ctfrac%7B2%7D%7B3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Further, they have an aspect ratio of
![\\sqrt{3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7B3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We shall see below that certain numbers related to parameters of these
ellipses play a role in certain in the counts of primitive
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
integer triangles.

Further, by means of a geometric construction we can show that for each
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
there 2 corresponding
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that can be derived from it, which share the lengths of 2 sides with the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle (Figure 8). This construction stems from the dissection of an
equilateral triangle into 3 triangles such that one of them will again
be equilateral (Figure 8). Thus, the primitive equilateral triangle
![(1,1,1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C1%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
defines a distinct primitive
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

[![120deg_60deg_triangles](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120deg_60deg_triangles.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/120deg_60deg_triangles.png)

Figure 8. 2 ![T\_{60}=(a, c,
a+b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D%3D%28a%2C+c%2C+a%2Bb%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
![(b, c,
a+b)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b%2C+c%2C+a%2Bb%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)can
be derived from a ![T\_{120}=(a, b,
c)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D%3D%28a%2C+b%2C+c%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
As with the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
family of triangle triples we can derive a formula for constructing the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples using two mutually prime integers ![u, v; u \>
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v%3B+u+%3E+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):

![x= u^2-v^2 y= 2uv+v^2 z=
u^2+uv+v^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D+u%5E2-v%5E2+y%3D+2uv%2Bv%5E2+z%3D+u%5E2%2Buv%2Bv%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Since these are necessarily scalene triangles, we order the triple ![(x,
y,
z)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2C+y%2C+z%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
such that elements are in ascending order and then term them ![(a, b,
c); a\<b\<
c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2C+b%2C+c%29%3B+a%3Cb%3C+c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Further, in order to get primitive triples, we have to again ensure that
the ![\\textrm{GCD}( u^2-v^2, 2uv+v^2,
u^2+uv+v^2)=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%28+u%5E2-v%5E2%2C+2uv%2Bv%5E2%2C+u%5E2%2Buv%2Bv%5E2%29%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
For example, ![u=4;
v=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D4%3B+v%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
while mutually prime and yield the triple ![(9, 15,
21)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%289%2C+15%2C+21%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which has
![\\textrm{GCD}=3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BGCD%7D%3D3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, it is merely the first triple ![(3, 5,
7)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%283%2C+5%2C+7%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
magnified 3 times. Hence, we have to drop such cases. Once we perform
this operation on the result of above formula we can get primitive
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. The first few are shown in Table 1.

![\\begin{tabular}{rrr} \\hline a & b & c \\\\ \\hline 3 & 5 & 7 \\\\ 7
& 8 & 13 \\\\ 5 & 16 & 19 \\\\ 11 & 24 & 31 \\\\ 7 & 33 & 37 \\\\ 13 &
35 & 43 \\\\ 16 & 39 & 49 \\\\ 9 & 56 & 61 \\\\ 32 & 45 & 67 \\\\ 17 &
63 & 73 \\\\ \\hline
\\end{tabular}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Btabular%7D%7Brrr%7D+%5Chline+a+%26+b+%26+c+%5C%5C+%5Chline+3+%26+5+%26+7+%5C%5C+7+%26+8+%26+13+%5C%5C+5+%26+16+%26+19+%5C%5C+11+%26+24+%26+31+%5C%5C+7+%26+33+%26+37+%5C%5C+13+%26+35+%26+43+%5C%5C+16+%26+39+%26+49+%5C%5C+9+%26+56+%26+61+%5C%5C+32+%26+45+%26+67+%5C%5C+17+%26+63+%26+73+%5C%5C+%5Chline+%5Cend%7Btabular%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

If we plot the independent values ![a,
b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%2C+b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples then they occupy a sector of the ellipse whose shape is the same
as the ellipse equation
![x^2+xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 9, panel 1). Further, the corresponding plot of the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
points shows them forming subtle circular patterns within the sector
which relate to their defining rational points on circles (Figure 2).
Here, we see the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
points form ellipses with a shape and inclination corresponding to the
![x^2+xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
ellipse on which they define rational points (Figure 9, panel 1).

[![triples_sectors](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_sectors.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples_sectors.png)Figure
9. The ordered primitive
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples (panel 1) sorted by
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The ordered primitive
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples sorted by middle side
![b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(panel 2). The ordered primitive
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples sorted by the longest side
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(panel 3).

Because of the defining relationship
![a^2+ab+b^2=c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bab%2Bb%5E2%3Dc%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples contains a central term we were able to derive only 1
transformation matrix
![\\mathbf{M}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for these triples. Unlike the trifurcating matrices for the right
triangle triples this one merely converts one primitive triple in to
another with no particular hierarchy:

![M= \\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 & 4\\\\ 3 & 4 & 4\\\\ 6 & 6 & 7\\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+4+%26+3+%26+4%5C%5C+3+%26+4+%26+4%5C%5C+6+%26+6+%26+7%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

If ![T\_{120}^0 = \\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\\\ 5 \\\\ 7 \\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D%5E0+%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+3+%5C%5C+5+%5C%5C+7+%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![\\mathbf{M \\cdot
T\_{120}^0=T\_{120}^{14}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM+%5Ccdot+T_%7B120%7D%5E0%3DT_%7B120%7D%5E%7B14%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![T\_{120}^{14} = \\begin{bmatrix} 55 \\\\ 57 \\\\ 97 \\\\
\\end{bmatrix}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D%5E%7B14%7D+%3D+%5Cbegin%7Bbmatrix%7D+55+%5C%5C+57+%5C%5C+97+%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bbmatrix%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We observe that the multiplication of
![\\mathbf{M}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbf%7BM%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
by
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
drives the triples towards the sides of a ![30^\\circ - 30^\\circ -
120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=30%5E%5Ccirc+-+30%5E%5Ccirc+-+120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle. Thus, for the triples generated by this multiplication we have
an arithmetic mean relationship comparable to the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples:

![\\textrm{AM}\\left(\\dfrac{c}{a}, \\dfrac{c}{b} \\right) \\to
\\sqrt{3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctextrm%7BAM%7D%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7Bc%7D%7Ba%7D%2C+%5Cdfrac%7Bc%7D%7Bb%7D+%5Cright%29+%5Cto+%5Csqrt%7B3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

In terms of the location of the rational points corresponding to the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples we see a fractal structure of “zones of inhibition” just as with
the right-triangle triples. However, there is no obvious pattern beyond
the higher ranked triples being associated with stronger zones of
inhibition (Figure 10).

![T120_distribution](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/t120_distribution.png)  
Figure 10. Location of the rational points corresponding to the
high-ranked
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples.

As with the right triangles we can ask what will be counts of
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples with ![c \\le
N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c+%5Cle+N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)?
We empirically ascertained it to be (Figure 11):

![\\dfrac{\\#(a, b, c \\le N)}{N} \\simeq
\\dfrac{\\sqrt{3}}{4\\pi}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%7D%7BN%7D+%5Csimeq+%5Cdfrac%7B%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D%7B4%5Cpi%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

[![triples120_counts](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples120_counts.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples120_counts.png)  
Figure 11. ![\\dfrac{\\sqrt{3}}{4\\pi} \\approx
0.1378322](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D%7B4%5Cpi%7D+%5Capprox+0.1378322&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Following the idea behind Lehmer’s proof for the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples, we can see that just as in that case the bounding curve of the
triple-generating coprime
![u,v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is a circle of radius
![N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
for
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples it is an ellipse of the form
![x^2+xy+y^2=N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3DN&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
One can see that this has a shape corresponding to
![x^2+xy+y^2=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bxy%2By%5E2%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 7, 9, panel 2). The area of this ellipse is ![\\tfrac{2 N
\\pi}{\\sqrt{3}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B2+N+%5Cpi%7D%7B%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 7). When the triples are in ascending order they only map to the
sector of the ellipse from
![x=0..\\sqrt{\\tfrac{N}{3}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D0..%5Csqrt%7B%5Ctfrac%7BN%7D%7B3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The explicit equation of the ellipse is ![y= \\tfrac{1}{2} (\\sqrt{4N -
3x^2} -
x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3D+%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D+%28%5Csqrt%7B4N+-+3x%5E2%7D+-+x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Hence, we can find the area occupied by the ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to the ordered
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples thus:

![\\displaystyle
\\int\_{0}^{\\sqrt{\\frac{N}{3}}}\\frac{1}{2}\\left(\\sqrt{4N-3x^{2}}-x\\right)dx\\
-\\frac{N}{6}= \\dfrac{N
\\pi}{6\\sqrt{3}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cint_%7B0%7D%5E%7B%5Csqrt%7B%5Cfrac%7BN%7D%7B3%7D%7D%7D%5Cfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D%5Cleft%28%5Csqrt%7B4N-3x%5E%7B2%7D%7D-x%5Cright%29dx%5C+-%5Cfrac%7BN%7D%7B6%7D%3D+%5Cdfrac%7BN+%5Cpi%7D%7B6%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This is just
![\\tfrac{1}{12}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B12%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the total area of the ellipse. Further, we have to apply a correction
factor as we are only considering primitive triples; some of the coprime
![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
yield the same triple when reduced. If we take first 4 coprime pairs
(2,1); (3,1); (3,2); (4,1) get the 4 triples (3,5,7); (7,8,13); (5, 16,
19); (9, 15, 21). Of these the last is not primitive being equivalent to
the first. Thus, we keep approximately only
![\\tfrac{3}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the triples coming from coprime
![(u,v)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28u%2Cv%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, the approximate number of primitive
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples such that ![\\#(a, b, c \\le N)= \\tfrac{6}{\\pi^2} \\cdot
\\tfrac{N \\pi}{6\\sqrt{3}} \\cdot
\\tfrac{3}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%3D+%5Ctfrac%7B6%7D%7B%5Cpi%5E2%7D+%5Ccdot+%5Ctfrac%7BN+%5Cpi%7D%7B6%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D+%5Ccdot+%5Ctfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which leads to the above result for the count of
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples.

We saw above that each
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple generates 2
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. Thus, the asymptotic count of
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples would be twice that of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. Further, given the specific geometric relationship between the
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle and its two
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle children, the longest side
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the
![120^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=120%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangle (Figure 8) is the middle side
![b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the two
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
children triangles if we consider their sides ![a, b,
c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%2C+b%2C+c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
in the ascending order. Hence, to observe the this relationship in the
asymptotic counts we need to sort the
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples by the middle side
![b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is the equivalent of
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples (Figure 12). This is also apparent from the sector of the
ellipse
![x^2-xy+y^2=N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2-xy%2By%5E2%3DN&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
occupied by the coprime
![u,v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
giving rise to the
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples (Figure 7, 9). This corresponds to the sector of the ellipse
defined by
![x=0..\\sqrt{N}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D0..%5Csqrt%7BN%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
By integrating between those limits one can see that the sector has
twice the area of sector occupied by the
![u,v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
generating
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

[![triples60_counts](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples60_counts.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples60_counts.png)Figure
12. Asymptotic counts of
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles sorted by the middle side
![b](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
![\\dfrac{\\#(a, b \\le N, c)}{N} \\simeq \\dfrac{\\sqrt{3}}{2\\pi}
\\approx
0.2756644](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5C%23%28a%2C+b+%5Cle+N%2C+c%29%7D%7BN%7D+%5Csimeq+%5Cdfrac%7B%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D%7B2%5Cpi%7D+%5Capprox+0.2756644&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

If we instead order the
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples by their longest sides
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then we get the below relationship for their asymptotic counts:

![\\dfrac{\\#(a, b, c \\le N)}{N} \\simeq
\\dfrac{9\\log(3)}{4\\pi^2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%7D%7BN%7D+%5Csimeq+%5Cdfrac%7B9%5Clog%283%29%7D%7B4%5Cpi%5E2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This can be empirically verified (Figure 13) and explained thus: If
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the longest side then the relationship between the individual
elements of a
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples is given as
![a^2+c^2-ac=b^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5E2%2Bc%5E2-ac%3Db%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Dividing this equation by
![c^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and writing ![x=\\tfrac{a}{c},
y=\\tfrac{b}{c}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D%5Ctfrac%7Ba%7D%7Bc%7D%2C+y%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bb%7D%7Bc%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we get the hyperbola
![y^2=x^2-x+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5E2%3Dx%5E2-x%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This hyperbola will determine the shape of the bounding curve of the
coprime ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
generating
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples with ![c \\le
N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c+%5Cle+N&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 9, panel 3). The actual equation of the bounding curve will be
![y^2=x^2-\\sqrt{N}x+N](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5E2%3Dx%5E2-%5Csqrt%7BN%7Dx%2BN&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, the generating ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will be contained in an area corresponding to the sector of this
hyperbola from
![x=0..\\sqrt{N}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%3D0..%5Csqrt%7BN%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 9, panel 3). We can get that area thus:

![\\displaystyle \\int\_{0}^{\\sqrt{N}}\\sqrt{x^{2}-\\sqrt{N}x+N}\\
dx-\\frac{N}{2}= \\dfrac{N}{2}+\\dfrac{3N\\log(3)}{8} - \\dfrac{N}{2} =
\\dfrac{3N\\log(3)}{8}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cint_%7B0%7D%5E%7B%5Csqrt%7BN%7D%7D%5Csqrt%7Bx%5E%7B2%7D-%5Csqrt%7BN%7Dx%2BN%7D%5C+dx-%5Cfrac%7BN%7D%7B2%7D%3D+%5Cdfrac%7BN%7D%7B2%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B3N%5Clog%283%29%7D%7B8%7D+-+%5Cdfrac%7BN%7D%7B2%7D+%3D+%5Cdfrac%7B3N%5Clog%283%29%7D%7B8%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Hence, in this case we get the approximate number of primitive
![T\_{60}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B60%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples such that ![\\#(a, b, c \\le N)= \\tfrac{6}{\\pi^2} \\cdot
\\tfrac{3N\\log(3)}{8}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%3D+%5Ctfrac%7B6%7D%7B%5Cpi%5E2%7D+%5Ccdot+%5Ctfrac%7B3N%5Clog%283%29%7D%7B8%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which is the above result.  
[![triples60_count_c](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples60_count_c.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/12/triples60_count_c.png)Figure
13. Asymptotic counts of
![60^\\circ](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=60%5E%5Ccirc&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triangles sorted by the longest side
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
![\\dfrac{\\#(a, b, c \\le N)}{N} \\simeq \\dfrac{9\\log(3)}{4\\pi^2}
\\approx
0.2504536](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%5C%23%28a%2C+b%2C+c+%5Cle+N%29%7D%7BN%7D+%5Csimeq+%5Cdfrac%7B9%5Clog%283%29%7D%7B4%5Cpi%5E2%7D+%5Capprox+0.2504536&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

**Divisibility and composition of triples**  
The triples illustrate a deep link between geometry and arithmetic in
terms of their divisibility and composition. Some of these facts have
probably been known since antiquity for the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. One trivial feature is that all the odd numbers will be
represented among the shortest sides for both the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. Since adjacent odd and even numbers are coprime, and thus valid
![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for generating the shortest side
![a](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
they give rise to the odd numbers because the difference of the squares
of two adjacent numbers is an odd number
![2n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Less trivially, in the case of the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples we also get the multiples of 4 starting from 8 onward as the
shortest side
![a](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This happens when we have even numbers couple with 1 (being naturally
coprime), such as ![u=4,
v=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D4%2C+v%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Here
![b=u^2-v^2=15](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b%3Du%5E2-v%5E2%3D15&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![a=2uv=8](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%3D2uv%3D8&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
similarly, ![u=6,
v=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D6%2C+v%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
would yield ![b=35,
a=12](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b%3D35%2C+a%3D12&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and so on. In the case of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples we similarly have in addition to the odd numbers, all multiples
of 8 from 16 onward. These come from consecutive odd numbers, which
being coprime can be valid ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to generate
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples. Thus, ![u=2n+1,
v=2n+3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D2n%2B1%2C+v%3D2n%2B3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
yields
![a=8(n+1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%3D8%28n%2B1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which from the
![n=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
onward will yield 16, 24…

A further relationship is related to the hypotenuse
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of a primitive
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triple: it is always an integer of the form
![4n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This can be understood thusly: Given ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as the coprime generators of a primitive triple let them be respectively
odd and even coprime numbers. We can write
![u=2k+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D2k%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![v=2j](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v%3D2j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
![\\therefore c=u^2+v^2 = 4k^2+ 4k+ 1+ 4j^2=
4(k^2+k+j^2)+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctherefore+c%3Du%5E2%2Bv%5E2+%3D+4k%5E2%2B+4k%2B+1%2B+4j%5E2%3D+4%28k%5E2%2Bk%2Bj%5E2%29%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, the hypotenuse will be of the form
![4n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where ![n=1, 2,
3..](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D1%2C+2%2C+3..&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
A similar relationship exists for
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples where every longest side
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is always of the form ![6n+1; n=1,2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6n%2B1%3B+n%3D1%2C2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This is harder to demonstrate generally than for the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
example. But we can do it informally by breaking this down to multiple
cases. First, consider a coprime ![u,
v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2C+v&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which are successive odd and even numbers. We can write them as
![v=2k+1,
u=2k+2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v%3D2k%2B1%2C+u%3D2k%2B2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We then have ![c=u^2+uv+v^2=
6(2k^2+3k+1)+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3Du%5E2%2Buv%2Bv%5E2%3D+6%282k%5E2%2B3k%2B1%29%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is an integer of the form
![6n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Second, if we a consecutive odd coprime numbers, e.g. 1, 3 they will be
of the form ![u=2k+3,
v=2k+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D2k%2B3%2C+v%3D2k%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then ![c=6(2k^2 + 4k +
2)+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3D6%282k%5E2+%2B+4k+%2B+2%29%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which is an integer of the form
![6n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Now, if we instead consider a coprime pair of the form ![u=2k+4,
v=2k+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D2k%2B4%2C+v%3D2k%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then ![c=u^2+uv+v^2= 3(4k^2 + 10k +
7)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3Du%5E2%2Buv%2Bv%5E2%3D+3%284k%5E2+%2B+10k+%2B+7%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This number will not be of the form
![6n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
but will be eliminated from the list because it is not a primitive
triple being divisible by 3. For example, as we saw above while applying
the correction factor for the counts, ![u=4,
v=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D4%2C+v%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
or ![u=8,
v=3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3D8%2C+v%3D3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are such eliminated pairs. By extending this argument we can see that
the only
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that remain will be of the form
![6n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6n%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
because the other coprime
![u,v](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
pairs will generate non-primitive triples.

For the
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples there is another interesting pattern: The most primitive triple
is ![3, 4,
5](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=3%2C+4%2C+5&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
At least 1 of the 3 sides of every subsequent primitive triple will be
divisible by 3, 4 and 5. For example: sorted by the hypotenuse
![c](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the 29th triple ![T\_{90}^{29}= 57, 176,
185](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D%5E%7B29%7D%3D+57%2C+176%2C+185&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
has the 1st side divisible by 3, the 2nd by 4 and the 3rd by 5. The 30th
triple ![T\_{90}^{30}= 104, 153,
185](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D%5E%7B30%7D%3D+104%2C+153%2C+185&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
has the 1st side divisible by 4, the 2nd by 3, and the 3rd by 5. In
other cases, 2 of these might divide the same side: e.g. ![T\_{90}^{2}=
5, 12,
13](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D%5E%7B2%7D%3D+5%2C+12%2C+13&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where 5 divides the 1st side and 3, 4 divide the second. Sometimes all 3
numbers might divide the same side, e.g. ![T\_{90}^{9}= 11, 60,
61](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D%5E%7B9%7D%3D+11%2C+60%2C+61&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where the 2nd side is divisible by 3, 4, 5. A comparable relationship
exists for
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples: at least 1 of the 3 sides of the triple will be divided by at
least 2 of the following numbers: 3, 5, 7, 8. Of these 3, 5, and 8
divide at least 1 side of around
![\\tfrac{2}{3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B2%7D%7B3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples and 7 divides at least one side of around
![\\tfrac{3}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the
![T\_{120}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B120%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
triples.

Finally, in passing, one may also note that it has been known for a
while that the terms meru-średhi (known in the occident as the Fibonacci
sequence) can be used to generate particular
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Let ![f=1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8,
13...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%3D1%2C+1%2C+2%2C+3%2C+5%2C+8%2C+13...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
be the średhi, then a
![T\_{90}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T_%7B90%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

![x = f\[n\] \\cdot f\[n+3\]\\\\ y = 2f\[n+1\] \\cdot f\[n+2\]\\\\ z =
f\[2n+3\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x+%3D+f%5Bn%5D+%5Ccdot+f%5Bn%2B3%5D%5C%5C+y+%3D+2f%5Bn%2B1%5D+%5Ccdot+f%5Bn%2B2%5D%5C%5C+z+%3D+f%5B2n%2B3%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
For example, if we take
![n=5](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D5&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),

Inspired this, we can derive a similar formula of the

For example if we take
