likely fueled their great march out of Africa that in the end spanned 5
continents and the entire range of ecosystems from wet-land forests, to
dry-lands, to the frozen Arctic. But this march that spanned over 20
million years suddenly came to a halt some time after about 1 Mya. A
wave of extinction of the elephants was seen first in the Old World and
sometime between 20000-7500 years before present in the New World. What
was the cause of this? While some ecologists like to blame climate
change, we hold that there is little doubt that things point to the hand
of *Homo*.

![elephants_vanderGeer](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/elephants_vandergeer.jpg)Figure
3. The global spread of some extinct elephant skeletons from Van der
Geer et al 2016; DOI: 10.1111/jbi.127431. 1.European *Palaeoloxodon
antiquus*; 2. North American *Mammuthus columbi*; 3. Asian *Stegodon
zdanskyi*; 4. Southern European *Elephas mnaidriensis*; 5. Mediterranean
pygmy *Palaeoloxodon falconeri*; 6. Channel Islands *Mammuthus exilis*;
7. Japanese *Stegodon aurorae*

The roll-back of the elephants corresponds to the major expansion of
*Homo* beyond Africa. Indeed, elephants are seen at human feeding and
kill sites throughout this period. Notably, the last elephants of the
lineages that became extinct are seen in refugia where humans did not
initially reach: The remote Wrangel Island in the Arctic ocean had
Mammuthus until around 4000 YBP and these finally vanished around the
time *Homo* first settled on the island. Similarly, in SA the
gomphotheres persisted in refugia until around 8000-7500 YBP before
their complete extirpation by the paleo-South Americans. It is
conceivable that there was a faint memory of recently extinct elephants
in human tradition. For example, the Mahābhārata records [a giant
elephant-like
animal](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2015/04/29/upakatha-of-previous-sulapuru%e1%b9%a3a-catvarakam-2/)
in the legend of the brāhmaṇa in the pit. As a large species with a long
maturation time and a slow rate of reproduction, what was once a key to
their success became their Achilles heel when faced with a
super-predator like *Homo* who wiped out the reproductive adults before
they could be replaced. Thus, the empire of the giants came crashing to
the floor.

One may ask but what about the elephants of Africa and India? How did
they survive the assault of *Homo*. Some have offered the suggestion
that the long presence of *Homo* in these regions allowed
co-evolutionary responses that allowed them to cope with him. It is
possible that some behavioral adaptation of such a type exists – e.g.
aggressiveness towards *Homo*. However, as others have pointed out (e.g.
Surovell et al) that the more likely reason was that only the elephants
from forest environments, where sizable populations of *Homo* could not
be supported, made it past the slaughter. Indeed, while *Homo* branched
off from his closest cousins in a dense forest biome where they still
grimly hang on today, the rise of the predecessors of *Homo*
corresponded to his march into more open environments. Ironically, this
opening of African environments into mixed wood- and grass-land habitats
might have been triggered by the massive megafaunal expansion in the
Pliocene, which also marked the emergence of the lineage leading to
*Homo.* The work of O’Brien’s team using molecular data has shown that
the savanna elephants of Africa, i.e. *Loxodonta,* experienced a greater
population bottleneck than their forest counterparts, suggesting that
being in more open habitats they experienced the heavy hand of *Homo.*
Further, the extinction actually depended on the developments in the
intelligence and technology of *Homo.* For instance, when archaic *Homo*
first reached India he was probably not capable of completely wiping off
all elephants. But probably sometime around 50 Kya the sapiens species
of *Homo* was able develop hunting methods that allowed targeting of
accessible elephant species. This was evidently the cause for the end of
*Palaeoloxodon namadicus*by 24 Kya in India. Likewise, in the Americas
the spread of the Clovis hunters and their successors probably was the
key point in delivering the final blow to the elephants of the New
World. This has gone on to our times as newer weaponry comes into being
and newer races of *H.sapiens*reach places where they were previously
absent. This is what marked the demise of the cheetah and the near end
of the lion in Asia and the various faunae of Australia and New Zealand.
Now that *Homo’s* gun-hand can penetrate the forest with ease, the
remaining two species of elephants would also be wiped out in the
relatively near future in the absence of a directed conservation effort.

**The sloths and their demise**  
The elephants were a relatively late addition to the South American
landscape, coming in only after the completion of the Panaman isthmus.
South America had its own iconic megafaunae even when landmass was
isolated from the north. The fate of one of those indigenous components
of the fauna also paralleled that of the elephant-new-comers. These were
the xenarthrans, remarkable components of the uniquely South American
faunae, one of the great placental lineages, which included the sloths,
the anteaters, armadillos and glyptodonts. These were enormously
successful animals, which, during the great American biotic interchange,
were one of few lineages of Southern mammals that successfully made it
to and colonized the North. In fact, they were early movers, and reached
Central and North America even before the isthmus of Panama was
complete. On the other side they colonized the West Indies, with an
extensive presence in the Greater Antilles and Cuba. Once in the North,
they advanced further, with the Thomas Jefferson’s sloth (*Megalonyx
jeffersonii*) reaching Alaska. Indeed, they might have even made it all
the way to the Old World across Beringia had their world not come to an
abrupt end as we shall see below.

Today we have only two genera of sloths, the two-fingered sloths
(*Choloepus*) and the three-fingered sloths (*Bradypus*), small arboreal
forest mammals living in regions not easily accessible to humans. They
are a pale reminder of the once glorious radiation of the sloth clade of
xenarthrans that spanned a great diversity of behaviors and sizes. We
had the giant ground sloths like *Megatherium*that grew up to 6 meters
in length. We had marine Megatheriid sloths like *Thalassocnus*, which
progressively acquired aquatic adaptations and grew up to 3.3 meters in
length. Then there were ground sloths which modified the very landscape
of parts of Brazil and Argentina, where they dug up numerous burrows in
hard substrates ranging in diameter from 1.5 to 4 meters. While the
species which created them are not known, based on their size they could
have been the work of sloths like *Glossotherium*, *Scelidotherium*,
*Ocnotherium*or *Lestodon*. Further, they successfully survived the
arrival of competing Northern herbivores, like the elephants, and new
predators, like the cats and the bears, during the faunal interchange.
Notably, some giant sloths like *Eremotherium*often co-occur with
elephants after their arrival in South America suggesting that they had
partitioned into different niches in the same habitat, thereby
recreating a setting like the African bush.

![sloths_small](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/sloths_small.jpg)Figure
4. Sloths by Jorge Blanco

The relationships of these sloths were enigmatic until recently, but as
their demise was not so long ago it has been possible to use ancient DNA
and paleo-proteomic approaches to address the problem. Recently
published studies suggest an interesting evolutionary scenario for the
sloths, wherein the Caribbean sloths *Acratocnus ye*and *Parocnus
serus*form the basal-most lineage. The next to branch off was the clade
uniting the Mylodontids and the 2-fingered sloths. The third clade
includes all the Megatherioids and the 3-fingered sloths. Within it the
South American Megatheriids are the basal-most lineage. The North
American Megalonychids and Nothrotheriids form the immediate
sister-group of the 3-fingered sloths. This suggests that either the
arboreal adaptation evolved twice in the 2- and 3- fingered sloths or
that there was an ancestral arboreal tendency from which the ground
sloths repeatedly emerged. The latter is supported by the arboreal
tendencies observed in the West Indian sloths (Figure 4). Further, this
phylogeny also suggests that the sloths reached the West Indies via an
early land bridge long before the connection of the North and South
American continents.

**The survivors of the *Homo* Blitzkrieg**  
Strikingly, the end of the sloths closely paralleled that of the
elephants, which were only recent arrivals to the South. After an
enormously successful run that spanned tens of millions of years,
sometime around 10000 YBP, they all but completely vanished in the
continental Americas. Subsequently, around 4400 YBP they vanished
entirely in the West Indies. This pattern is telling as it parallels the
fate of the last of the extinct Elephantids on isolated islands, where
they vanished much after the mainland and typically only after humans
arrived. Like elephants, sloths such as *Megatherium americanum*too
have been found in butchery sites of *Homo* in the Americas from around
12600 YBP. There have been major climatic changes and concomitant
shrinkage of ranges, loss of habitats and background extinctions going
on all while before the origin of *Homo.* However, new species fill
those that are lost through convergent evolution or the old lineages
recover after a while. The pattern we observe here is nothing like that,
especially given that many of the lineages that vanished so dramatically
across continents had been successful in weathering the climatic changes
and background extinctions over tens of millions of years. Thus, despite
the fashionable statements among some ecologists and paleontologists
pinning everything on climate, we have to conclude that *Homo* squarely
stands accused.

All this happened with almost the suddenness of a mass extinction due to
astronomical causes, but, unlike in those cases, many of the plants once
adapted to the megafauna remain intact. Indeed, the ecologists Dan
Janzen and Paul Martin, who first noted these anomalies in their
brilliant paper “Neotropical Anachronisms: The Fruits the Gomphotheres
Ate” noted several examples from the New World of what might be remnants
of now lost adaptations of plants to megafauna. For example they propose
that large clusters of thorns of the legume known as the honey locust
tree might have been an adaptation against browsing by the now extinct
elephants. Some of them, like the avocado, which was once on the menu of
the great sloths, might have found a new partner in their extirpators,
i.e. *Homo.* Others have proposed that the osage orange might have
survived because some early Americans used the tree to make bows and
subsequently due to the horses brought by Europeans taking up the role
of their dispersers (see Barlow’s excellent popular account of the
same). Hence, one would predict that new megafaunae might arise again
once *Homo* himself goes the way of extinction.

**Śrīpati’s pearl necklace for Maheśvara**  
The brāhmaṇa Śrīpati of the Kāśyapa clan was a soothsayer from
Rohiṇīkhaṇḍa, which is in the modern Buldhana district of Maharashtra
state. Somewhere between 1030 to 1050 CE he composed several works on
mathematics, astronomy and divination, one of which is the Gaṇita-tilaka
on basic arithmetic and algebra which has come down to us through
incomplete manuscripts. In that he posses the following problem (The
solution is provided by his Jaina commentator Siṃhatilaka Sūri in 1275
CE):

viśva-kha-sapta-bhujaṅga-navārkāḥ śaila-turaṅga-samāhata-dehāḥ \|  
syāt sphuṭa-tāraka-vartula-muktā-bhūṣaṇam atra maheśvara-kaṇṭhe \|\|  
The bodies of all (13), the space (0), the seven (7), the snakes (8),
the nine (9) and the suns (12) struck together (means multiplied in
mathematical terminology) with the mountains (7) and the horses (7) may
now be the clear, sparkling and globular pearls forming an ornament for
the neck of Maheśvara.

The purpose of the problem is two-fold: (1) to make the student familiar
with using the Hindu numerical code (the bhūta-saṃkhya) and (2) make the
student do some elementary large number multiplication. Thus, the
problem is actually a simple multiplication ![12987013 \\times
77](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=12987013+%5Ctimes+77&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
whose answer is
![1000000001](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1000000001&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Interestingly, Śrīpati offers a clue for the answer in the problem
itself: he says the multiplication of the 2 numbers results in a
necklace of clear, sparkling, spherical pearls for Maheśvara. This is
clearly an allusion to the palindromic structure of the product, with
the 0s forming the pearls, since they were written historically as
circles and the two flanking 1s form the bindings of the necklace. Some
numerical savants are known to exhibit a synesthesia with respect
numbers — perhaps such was indeed the situation with Śrīpati for a
palindromic number such as this could simultaneously produce in ones
mind the vivid image of a pearl necklace.

Moreover, this is not just any pearl necklace but one for Rudra’s neck.
It is in this regard we believe he encoded more into that number. As we
can see from the above, one of the factors of 1000000001 is 11, which is
the characteristic number of the Rudra-s. At the same time, the Rudra-s
are also said to be 1000s upon 1000s (Yajurveda: sahasrāṇi sahasraśo ye
rudrā adhi bhūmyām \|). Thus, this product captures both those aspects.
Further, the numbers that yield the product are described in
bhūta-saṃkhya (itself eminently amenable synesthetic experience of
numbers) as including viśvā (= all); kha (= space); 7, which symbolizes
the heavenly realms or vyāhṛti-s, the 8 directional earth-bearing
snakes, the 9, which symbolizes the planets, the 12 Āditya-s on one hand
and the 7 continental mountain ranges and 7 solar horses on the other.
Thus, the two numbers are described by the entities of entire universe
pervaded by the 1000s of Rudra-s with their 11-fold essence and their
product is seen yielding a necklace for Maheśvara. In this regard, the
use of viśva for 13 is curious. In the bhūta-saṃkhya system, viśva
represents the viśvedeva-s (all gods). In the gaṇapāṭha database from
which Pāṇini constructed his grammar we find viśvadeva as entry 13 in
the manojñādi-gaṇa (GP 177.13), thus lending viśva to encode 13.

**Maheśvara’s necklace sequence and its factors**  
Taking the cue from Śrīpati, we can define a general integer sequence
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of Maheśvara’s necklaces thusly:
![f\[n\]=10^n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3D10%5En%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is an integer and
![f\[n\]^m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%5Em&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![m=1,2,3,4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D1%2C2%2C3%2C4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
is also palindromic. This implies that ![n=1, 2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D1%2C+2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
Thus, the first few terms of our sequence are:  
**11, 101, 1001, 10001, 100001, 1000001, 10000001, 100000001,
1000000001, 10000000001…**

We can next ask what are the factors of each
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The first few
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are factorized and tabulated below:

Table
1[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_table1.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_table1.png)

From the above one may notice a few obvious things. The first 2 terms of
the sequence are primes, 11 and 101, but all others are composites. It
is also obvious that 3 can never be a factor of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
because the sum of the digits of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will never be 3. We also observe that many of the
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
have a tendency to have a mix of small factors with a very large one.
Śrīpati’s original example
![f\[9\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B9%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is one such: ![f\[9\]=7\\times 11\\times 13\\times 19\\times
52579](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B9%5D%3D7%5Ctimes+11%5Ctimes+13%5Ctimes+19%5Ctimes+52579&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We can then ask questions such as: 1) which primes will divide a given
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
2) For which
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will a given prime
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
be a factor of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
3) Knowing these, we can ask questions, such as, at what further
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will we get a
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that will be again divisible by 52579, i.e. they will be further
Maheśvara’s necklaces of the type specified by Śrīpati.

We notice right away that 11 divides every other term, i.e. whenever
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is odd. We also notice that 101 is a factor of
![f\[2\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B2%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and every 4th term thereafter. Thus, we can formally write that 11
divides every
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
when
![n=2k+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D2k%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![k=0,1,2,3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k%3D0%2C1%2C2%2C3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Similarly, 101 divides every
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
when
![n=4k+2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D4k%2B2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, it also becomes obvious that 11 and 101 will never be co-factors
of the same
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
With closer observation we can see that every prime
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that divides a subset of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
does so at some ![n=m\\cdot
k+\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3Dm%5Ccdot+k%2B%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![m=2,4,6,8...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D2%2C4%2C6%2C8...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):
the reason for writing it this way will become clear below. The first
few
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that divide
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for some
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are tabulated in the order of how often they do so along with the form
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
takes when
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is divisible by that
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):

Table
2[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_table2.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_table2.png)

At first site the order in which the primes which divide
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
appear beyond 11 and 101 is puzzling — they wildly differ in magnitude
and form. However, a closer examination reveals a striking pattern
behind this: a prime
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
appears in the above list as per the [*multiplicative
order*](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2018/11/03/fermats-little-theorem-and-the-periods-of-the-reciprocals-of-primes/)
of 10 modulo
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):
consider ![10^j \\mod
p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej+%5Cmod+p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where ![j=1, 2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3D1%2C+2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
when for the first time ![10^j \\mod p =
1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej+%5Cmod+p+%3D+1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
that
![j](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is
![m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the multiplicative order of ![10 \\mod
p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10+%5Cmod+p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Carl Gauss had famously shown in his *Disquisitiones Arithmeticae* that
![m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the length of the repeat pattern of the decimal expansion of
![\\tfrac{1}{p}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7Bp%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, it is also clear that
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divides
![10^j-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the first time when
![j=m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3Dm&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
For example, for 7 we get
![m=6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
because 7 divides
![10^j-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the first time when
![j=6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to give
![\\tfrac{999999}{7}=142857](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B999999%7D%7B7%7D%3D142857&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Likewise, the repeat pattern in the decimal expansion of
![\\tfrac{1}{7}=0.\\overline{142857}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B7%7D%3D0.%5Coverline%7B142857%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is of length 6. From the above we can easily see why a
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will divide
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
first time when
![n=\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, the sequence of
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that divide
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the first time will be arranged as per the multiplicative order of
![10 \\mod
p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10+%5Cmod+p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):

![10^m-1=
10^{(m/2)^2}-1=(10^{m/2}-1)(10^{m/2}+1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Em-1%3D+10%5E%7B%28m%2F2%29%5E2%7D-1%3D%2810%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D-1%29%2810%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D%2B1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Now
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divides
![10^j-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the first time when
![j=m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3Dm&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Hence, it will not divide
![10^{m/2}-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
However, because
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divides
![10^m-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Em-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
it therefore divides
![10^{m/2}+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Now what if
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divides some factor of
![10^{m/2}+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which takes the form ![10^j+1; j=1, 2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej%2B1%3B+j%3D1%2C+2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)?
We can see from polynomial factorization that a polynomial of the form
![x^j+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Ej%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
can frequently have two factors of the form ![x^j+1; j=1, 2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Ej%2B1%3B+j%3D1%2C+2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
namely
![x+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
or
![x^2+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
For example,
![x^3+1=(x+1)(x^2-x+1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E3%2B1%3D%28x%2B1%29%28x%5E2-x%2B1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![x^6+1=(x^2+1)(x^4-x^2+1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E6%2B1%3D%28x%5E2%2B1%29%28x%5E4-x%5E2%2B1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Now, in our case ![x+1 \\equiv
11](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%2B1+%5Cequiv+11&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and ![x^2+1 \\equiv
101](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2B1+%5Cequiv+101&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Those are primes and the first two terms of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
hence, they will not be divided by any other
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Now, less frequently, other numbers of the form
![10^j+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are divisors of another such number for a larger
![j](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
For example, 10001 is a divisor of 1000000000001. So, let us assume for
a moment that
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divides some
![10^l+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5El%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is a factor of
![10^{m/2}+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7Bm%2F2%7D%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
then
![l\<\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3C%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
If
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
does divides
![10^l+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5El%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
then it also divides
![10^{2l}-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7B2l%7D-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
But
![2l-1\<m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2l-1%3Cm&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
hence,
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
cannot divide it because it will only divide a number of of the form
![10^j-1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej-1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
when
![j=m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3Dm&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
i.e. the multiplicative order of ![10 \\mod
p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10+%5Cmod+p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus,
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
cannot divide any other
![10^l+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5El%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where
![l\<\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3C%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

The Maheśvara’s necklaces
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
are the sequence
![10^j+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5Ej%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
therefore they would be divided by a given
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for the first time when
![n=\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which is half the multiplicative order of ![10 \\mod p
\\;\_{...\\blacksquare}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10+%5Cmod+p+%5C%3B_%7B...%5Cblacksquare%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

By the procedure we followed above we can see that, after
![n=\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
would divide every
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where ![n=m\\cdot k+\\tfrac{m}{2}; k=1, 2,
3...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3Dm%5Ccdot+k%2B%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3B+k%3D1%2C+2%2C+3...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
A corollary to this is only
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
with even
![m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
can be factors of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for only then
![\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
would be an integer. Hence, those primes with odd
![m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
such as ![3,
m=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=3%2C+m%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
![37,
m=3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=37%2C+m%3D3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
etc will never be factors of any
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

Armed with the above, we can also tell which will be the next
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that will have 52579 as a factor as the original example of Śrīpati. For
52579, ![m=18 \\; \\therefore p \| f\[n\] \\iff n=18k+9; \\;
k=0,1,2...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D18+%5C%3B+%5Ctherefore+p+%7C+f%5Bn%5D+%5Ciff+n%3D18k%2B9%3B+%5C%3B+k%3D0%2C1%2C2...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
Hence, next term would be:  
![f\[27\]=1000000000000000000000000001](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B27%5D%3D1000000000000000000000000001&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We can also see that some
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will always come together as factors of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
because they have the same
![m](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, 7 and 13 with
![m=6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
or 19 and 52579 with
![m=18](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D18&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will always co-occur. Further, if a certain
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
satisfies the relationship ![n=m \\cdot k
+\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3Dm+%5Ccdot+k+%2B%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for a certain
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
also divides that
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will occur again as a factor of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
For example, consider ![n=6 \\times
3+3=21](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D6+%5Ctimes+3%2B3%3D21&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Now,
![m=6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
here; hence
![f\[21\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B21%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will be divisible by both 7 and 13 as they have
![m=6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
However, 7 divides 21. Hence, 7 will occur again as the factor of
![f\[21\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B21%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, we have: ![f\[21\]= \\underline{7} \\times \\underline{7} \\times
11 \\times 13 \\times 127 \\times 2689 \\times 909091 \\times
459691](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B21%5D%3D+%5Cunderline%7B7%7D+%5Ctimes+%5Cunderline%7B7%7D+%5Ctimes+11+%5Ctimes+13+%5Ctimes+127+%5Ctimes+2689+%5Ctimes+909091+%5Ctimes+459691&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Likewise, ![n=6 \\times 6
+3=39](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D6+%5Ctimes+6+%2B3%3D39&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
will correspond to a
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
divisible by both 7 and 13. However, as 39 is divisible by 13, we will
have 13 occur again as a factor of
![f\[39\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B39%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, ![f\[39\]=7 \\times 11 \\times \\underline{13} \\times
\\underline{13} \\times 157 \\times 859 \\times 6397 \\times 216451
\\times 1058313049 \\times
388847808493](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B39%5D%3D7+%5Ctimes+11+%5Ctimes+%5Cunderline%7B13%7D+%5Ctimes+%5Cunderline%7B13%7D+%5Ctimes+157+%5Ctimes+859+%5Ctimes+6397+%5Ctimes+216451+%5Ctimes+1058313049+%5Ctimes+388847808493&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
All other
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
would be square-free.

**The families of Maheśvara’s necklaces**

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig1.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig1.png)Figure
1

We can represent any given
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as a clique of its factors. For example, Figure 1 shows the dodecagonal
clique formed by the factors of
![f\[45\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B45%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
which the most composite
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
for
![n=1..50](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D1..50&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We then merge all cliques sharing common nodes for ![f\[n\],
n=1..50](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%2C+n%3D1..50&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The edges and the nodes are then scaled as per their frequency of
occurrence across all 50 cliques. The result is a factor graph for
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which is shown in Figure 2.

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig2.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig2.png)Figure
2 (click on figure to magnify)

We can see from Figure 2 that there are totally 6 families of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
in this range. These families can be described according to their
founder member which is then the divisor of the remaining
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of that family. The founder member of each family can be described as
the
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of the form ![10^{2^l}+1,
l=0,1,2...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10%5E%7B2%5El%7D%2B1%2C+l%3D0%2C1%2C2...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![2^l](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5El&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponds to a particular
![\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002):

● When ![l=0,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D0%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 11 family. 11, as we saw above, divides every
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to ![n=2k +
1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D2k+%2B+1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, every
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to an odd
![\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is drawn into this family, there making it the largest of them.  
● When ![l=1,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D1%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 101 family. 101 draws all
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to
![n=4k+2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D4k%2B2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus it becomes the largest of the even
![\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
families.  
● When ![l=2,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D2%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 1001 family. 1001 being composite is centered on its two
factors 73 and 137 and corresponds to the terms where
![n=8k+4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D8k%2B4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
● When ![l=3,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=8](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D3%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D8&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 100000001 family. This number being composite is centered on
its factors 17 and 5882353 and corresponds to the terms where
![n=16k+8](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D16k%2B8&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
● When ![l=4,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=16](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D4%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D16&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 10000000000000001 family centered on its factors 353, 449,
641, 1409 and 69857. This encompasses the terms corresponding to
![n=32k+16](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D32k%2B16&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
● When ![l=5,
\\tfrac{m}{2}=32](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=l%3D5%2C+%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D%3D32&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
we get the 100000000000000000000000000000001 family centered on its
factors 976193, 19841, 6187457 and 834427406578561. This includes the
terms corresponding to
![n=64k+32](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D64k%2B32&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

Thus, we find that the even
![\\tfrac{m}{2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bm%7D%7B2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
terms are split up among the various families that appear as per the
powers of 2.

**The largest factor of Maheśvara’s necklace**  
Given the above information, we can cut down the time in which we
factorize Maheśvara’s necklaces and gather the set of factors for the
first 300 terms of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We can then ask which is the largest prime
![p_m\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
which divides the corresponding
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Figure 3 shows the plot of
![\\log\_{10}p_m\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clog_%7B10%7Dp_m%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
against
![\\log\_{10}(f\[n\])](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clog_%7B10%7D%28f%5Bn%5D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig3.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig3.png)Figure
3

We see that the general increase of
![\\log\_{10}(p_m)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clog_%7B10%7D%28p_m%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
appears to be linear with
![\\log\_{10}(f\[n\])](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clog_%7B10%7D%28f%5Bn%5D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
It is bounded between lines ![y=a_ux,
y=a_lx](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3Da_ux%2C+y%3Da_lx&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
where
![a_u=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_u%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and ![a_l \\approx
0.1831](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_l+%5Capprox+0.1831&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The upper bounding slope
![a_u](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_u&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is easy to understand: as we observed above, some
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
tend to have factors widely differing in magnitude; thus the large one
is closer in magnitude to
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Trivially, first two terms are primes. There after we get
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that are minimally composite. These tend to be of a particular form,
e.g.:  
![f\[19\]=11 \\times
909090909090909091](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B19%5D%3D11+%5Ctimes+909090909090909091&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
![f\[31\]= 11 \\times
909090909090909090909090909091](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B31%5D%3D+11+%5Ctimes+909090909090909090909090909091&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
![f\[53\]= 11 \\times
9090909090909090909090909090909090909090909090909091](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B53%5D%3D+11+%5Ctimes+9090909090909090909090909090909090909090909090909091&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
Thus, these have factors that approach the upper bounding line.

The median value of ratio of
![p_m\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is approximately 0.5006. This indicates an even distribution with half
the number of
![p_m\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
being greater than the
![\\sqrt{f\[n\]}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7Bf%5Bn%5D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and the other half being lesser than
![\\sqrt{f\[n\]}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7Bf%5Bn%5D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

We understand the lower bound is less clearly. Is there a way to derive
it from theory alone? One can see that for
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
corresponding to multiples of 15 there is an increased propensity to be
close to the lower bound. This is in part expected from the
factorization of polynomial of the form
![x^n+1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5En%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
where
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is a multiple of 15. For example, we can see that:

![x^{13}+1=(x + 1) (x^{12} - x^{11} + x^{10} - x^9 + x^8 - x^7 + x^6 -
x^5 + x^4 - x^3 + x^2 - x + 1) \\\\\[5pt\] x^{14}+1=(x^2 + 1) (x^{12} -
x^{10} + x^8 - x^6 + x^4 - x^2 + 1) \\\\ \[5pt\] x^{15}+1=(x + 1) (x^2 -
x + 1) (x^4 - x^3 + x^2 - x + 1) (x^8 + x^7 - x^5 - x^4 - x^3 + x + 1)
\\\\ \[5pt\] x^{16}+1=x^{16} + 1 \\\\ \[5pt\] x^{17}+1=(x + 1) (x^{16} -
x^{15} + x^{14} - x^{13} + x^{12} - x^{11} + x^{10} - x^9 + x^8 - x^7 +
x^6 - x^5 + x^4 - x^3 + x^2 - x +
1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E%7B13%7D%2B1%3D%28x+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E%7B12%7D+-+x%5E%7B11%7D+%2B+x%5E%7B10%7D+-+x%5E9+%2B+x%5E8+-+x%5E7+%2B+x%5E6+-+x%5E5+%2B+x%5E4+-+x%5E3+%2B+x%5E2+-+x+%2B+1%29+%5C%5C%5B5pt%5D+x%5E%7B14%7D%2B1%3D%28x%5E2+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E%7B12%7D+-+x%5E%7B10%7D+%2B+x%5E8+-+x%5E6+%2B+x%5E4+-+x%5E2+%2B+1%29+%5C%5C+%5B5pt%5D+x%5E%7B15%7D%2B1%3D%28x+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E2+-+x+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E4+-+x%5E3+%2B+x%5E2+-+x+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E8+%2B+x%5E7+-+x%5E5+-+x%5E4+-+x%5E3+%2B+x+%2B+1%29+%5C%5C+%5B5pt%5D+x%5E%7B16%7D%2B1%3Dx%5E%7B16%7D+%2B+1+%5C%5C+%5B5pt%5D+x%5E%7B17%7D%2B1%3D%28x+%2B+1%29+%28x%5E%7B16%7D+-+x%5E%7B15%7D+%2B+x%5E%7B14%7D+-+x%5E%7B13%7D+%2B+x%5E%7B12%7D+-+x%5E%7B11%7D+%2B+x%5E%7B10%7D+-+x%5E9+%2B+x%5E8+-+x%5E7+%2B+x%5E6+-+x%5E5+%2B+x%5E4+-+x%5E3+%2B+x%5E2+-+x+%2B+1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

As one can see from the above example the polynomial where
![n=15](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D15&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
tends to have more factors than other polynomial adjacent to it. Thus,
these tend to be among highly composite
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
hence, they are more likely to have smaller
![p_m\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
than their neighbors.

**Tailpiece**  
Finally, let us look at some actual historical pearl ornaments of
Maheśvara. The below were likely ātmaliṅga-s of a medieval South Indian
ruler or a royal śaiva officiant.

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig4.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig4.png)Figure
4

In this example we see the first term of Maheśvara necklace sequence. 11
is of course the characteristic number of the Rudra-s. If we wish to add
the bottom two pearls which belong to a different register we get 13
which is the next most frequent factor of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig5.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/08/maheshvara_fig5.png)Figure
5

In this example we get two sets of pearl ornamentation one with 17 and
another with 7. Both of these are factors of
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
with 7 being the next most frequent and 17 the founder of a distinct
family. Of course there are other numbers with other symbolisms in these
ornaments.

For background also see:  
[Fermat’s little theorem and the periods of the reciprocals of
primes](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2018/11/03/fermats-little-theorem-and-the-periods-of-the-reciprocals-of-primes/)  
[Visualizing the Hindu divisibility
test](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2018/11/11/visualizing-the-hindu-divisibility-test/)

**The coin-toss problem and Nārāyaṇa’s sequence**  
If you toss a fair coin
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
times how many of the possible result-sequences of tosses will not have
a successive run of 3 or more Heads? The same can be phrased as given
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
tosses of a fair coin, what is the probability of not getting 3 or more
successive Heads in the result-sequence. For a single toss
![(n=1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%3D1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
we have two result-sequences
![H,T](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=H%2CT&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002);
so we have 2 result-sequences with no run of 3 or more continuous Heads.
Let
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
be the number of tosses,
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the number of result-sequences satisfying the condition and
![p](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
the probability of its occurrence. This can be tabulated for the first
few coin tosses as below:

![\\begin{tabular}{\|l\|p{0.5\\linewidth}\|l\|l\|} \\hline n & All
result-sequences & f\[n\] & p\\\\ \\hline 1 & H,T & 2 & 1\\\\ 2 & HH,
HT, TT, TH & 4 & 1\\\\ 3 & HHH, HHT, HTH, HTT, TTT, TTH, THH, THT & 7 &
0.875\\\\ 4 & HHHH, HHHT, HHTH, HTHH, HHTT, HTHT, HTTH, HTTT, TTTT,
TTTH, TTHT, THTT, TTHH, THHT, THTH, THHH & 13 & 0.8125\\\\ \\hline
\\end{tabular}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Btabular%7D%7B%7Cl%7Cp%7B0.5%5Clinewidth%7D%7Cl%7Cl%7C%7D+%5Chline+n+%26+All+result-sequences+%26+f%5Bn%5D+%26+p%5C%5C+%5Chline+1+%26+H%2CT+%26+2+%26+1%5C%5C+2+%26+HH%2C+HT%2C+TT%2C+TH+%26+4+%26+1%5C%5C+3+%26+HHH%2C+HHT%2C+HTH%2C+HTT%2C+TTT%2C+TTH%2C+THH%2C+THT+%26+7+%26+0.875%5C%5C+4+%26+HHHH%2C+HHHT%2C+HHTH%2C+HTHH%2C+HHTT%2C+HTHT%2C+HTTH%2C+HTTT%2C+TTTT%2C+TTTH%2C+TTHT%2C+THTT%2C+TTHH%2C+THHT%2C+THTH%2C+THHH+%26+13+%26+0.8125%5C%5C+%5Chline+%5Cend%7Btabular%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Thus we get the sequence as
![f\[n\]=2,4,7,13...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3D2%2C4%2C7%2C13...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
from which we can compute the probability as
![p=\\tfrac{f\[n\]}{2^n}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bf%5Bn%5D%7D%7B2%5En%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The question then arises at to whether there is a general formula for
![f\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The answer to this comes from a class of sequences described by the
great Hindu scientist Nārāyaṇa paṇḍita in 1356 CE. In his Gaṇita-kaumudī
he provides the following (first brought to the wider public attention
in modern times by Paramand Singh in his famous article on such
sequences):

ekāṅkau vinyasya prathamaṃ  
tat saṃyutiṃ puro vilikhet \|  
utkramato ‘ntima-tulya-  
sthānāṅka-yutim puro vilikhet \|\|  
First placing 1 twice ![f\[1\]=1;
f\[2\]=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B1%5D%3D1%3B+f%5B2%5D%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
write their sum ahead
![f\[3\]=f\[1\]+f\[2\]=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B3%5D%3Df%5B1%5D%2Bf%5B2%5D%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Write ahead of that, write the sum of numbers in reverse order \[and
in\] positions equal to the “terminal”
![(q)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28q%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

utkramato ‘ntima-tulya-  
sthāna-yutiṃ tat purastāc ca \|  
antima-tulya sthānābhave  
tat saṃyutiṃ purastāc ca \|\|  
evaṃ saika-samāsa-sthānā-sāmāsikīyaṃ syāt \|  
Write ahead of that, write the sum of numbers in reverse order \[and
in\] positions equal to the “terminal” (continue process). (This means:
If ![3 \\le n \\le
q](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=3+%5Cle+n+%5Cle+q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then
![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]+f\[n-2\]...f\[2\]+f\[1\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D...f%5B2%5D%2Bf%5B1%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002))
In the absence of \[numbers in\] positions equal to the terminal write
in the front the sum of those \[in available places\] (This means if
![q\<n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=q%3Cn&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then
![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]+f\[n-2\]...f\[n-q\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D...f%5Bn-q%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
). Thus, the numbers till the position one more than \[the prior\] may
be known as the additive sequence ![(f\[1\], f\[2\]...f\[n-q\],
f\[n-q+1\]...f\[n\])](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28f%5B1%5D%2C+f%5B2%5D...f%5Bn-q%5D%2C+f%5Bn-q%2B1%5D...f%5Bn%5D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

One will note that if one takes
![q=2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=q%3D2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then we get the famous mātrā-meru sequence
![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]+f\[n-2\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%2Bf%5Bn-2%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(known in the Occident as the Fibonacci sequence after Leonardo of
Pisa). Nārāyaṇa then goes on to provide a numerical example for this
class of additive sequences:  
udāharaṇam –  
samāse yatra sapta syur  
antimas trimitaḥ sakhe \|  
kīdṛśī tatra kathaya  
paṅktiḥ sāmāsikī drutam \|\|  
Now an example: Friend, if we have 7 in the sequence and 3 as the
“terminal”
![(q=3)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28q%3D3%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
then quickly say what will be the additive sequence under consideration.

The sequence in consideration in modern form starting from 0 will be
![f\[n\]=f\[n-1\]+f\[n+2\]+f\[n-3\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5Bn%5D%3Df%5Bn-1%5D%2Bf%5Bn%2B2%5D%2Bf%5Bn-3%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
with the first three terms being 0,1,1 (in Nārāyaṇa’s reckoning they
will be 1,1,2): **0, 1, 1, 2, 4, 7, 13, 24, 44, 81, 149, 274, 504, 927,
1705…** Thus, Nārāyaṇa’s numerical example from
![f\[3\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%5B3%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
onwards gives us the solution to the coin toss problem. In modern times
this sequence has been given the name “Tribonacci”. With this, one can
see that the probability of the getting a result-sequence without 3 or
more continuous heads decays with
![2^n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
asymptotically towards 0.

**The convergent of Nārāyaṇa’s sequence and problem of the triple
proportional partition of a segment**  
Consider the geometric problem: Partition a line segment
![\\overline{AD}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BAD%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
of length
![t_4](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_4&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
in 3 parts ![t_1, t_2,
t_3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_1%2C+t_2%2C+t_3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
such that ![\\tfrac{t_2}{t_1} =
\\tfrac{t_3}{t_2}=\\tfrac{t_4}{t_3}=\\tfrac{t_1+t_2+t_3}{t_3}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bt_2%7D%7Bt_1%7D+%3D+%5Ctfrac%7Bt_3%7D%7Bt_2%7D%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bt_4%7D%7Bt_3%7D%3D%5Ctfrac%7Bt_1%2Bt_2%2Bt_3%7D%7Bt_3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 1).

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig1.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig1.png)Figure
1

We can see that the above geometric process is equivalent to the
formulation of the above tryantima-sāmāsikā-paṅkti of Nārāyaṇa (Figure
1). This indicates that, at its limit, the convergent of the above
sequence of Nārāyaṇa,
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
will yield us the ratio in which the partition of the segment should be
performed. Thus, we have:

![\\tau= \\displaystyle \\lim\_{n \\to \\infty}\\dfrac{f\[n\]}{f\[n-1\]}
\\approx
1.8392867552141611325518525646532...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%3D+%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Clim_%7Bn+%5Cto+%5Cinfty%7D%5Cdfrac%7Bf%5Bn%5D%7D%7Bf%5Bn-1%5D%7D+%5Capprox+1.8392867552141611325518525646532...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This number, unlike the Golden ratio
![\\phi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cphi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
the convergent of the mātrā-meru-paṅkti, cannot be constructed using a
straight edge and a compass. However, as we shall see below, it can be
easily constructed using two simply specified conics which can in turn
be constructed using the geometric mean theorem or other standard
methods (Figure 2).

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig2.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig2.png)Figure
2

1\) Draw the parabola specified by
![y=x^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3Dx%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
with its vertex
![C](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as the origin.  
2) Draw a unit rectangular hyperbola with center
![C_h](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C_h&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
at
![(1,1)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Therefore, its equation will be
![xy-x-y=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=xy-x-y%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
3) The two conics will intersect at
![P](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Drop a perpendicular from
![P](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to the
![x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)-axis
to cut it at
![B](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
![t_1=\\overline{CB}=\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_1%3D%5Coverline%7BCB%7D%3D%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
4) Extend
![\\overline{CB}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BCB%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
by a unit to get point
![A](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
![\\overline{BA}=1](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BBA%7D%3D1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
5) Draw a circle with
![C](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as center and
![\\overline{CB}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BCB%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as radius to cut the
![x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)-axis
at
![X](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
6) Mark point
![Q](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
along
![\\overline{CB}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BCB%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
at a unit distance from
![C](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Join
![Q](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to
![X](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).  
7) Draw a perpendicular to
![\\overline{QX}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BQX%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
at
![X](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
It will cut the
![x](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)-Axis
at point
![D](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Join
![C](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to
![D](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
By the geometric mean theorem
![\\overline{CD}=\\tau^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BCD%7D%3D%5Ctau%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

This gives us the required partition of
![\\overline{AD}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BAD%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
into 3 segments each proportional to the other as
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
and
![\\overline{AD}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BAD%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
proportional to the largest partition
![\\overline{CD}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Coverline%7BCD%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
again as
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, we have:

![\\tau=\\dfrac{\\tau^2+\\tau+1}{\\tau^2}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%3D%5Cdfrac%7B%5Ctau%5E2%2B%5Ctau%2B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Hence,
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is the root of the cubic equation
![\\tau^3-\\tau^2-\\tau-1=0](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%5E3-%5Ctau%5E2-%5Ctau-1%3D0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, we see that the above construction is achieved by solving this
cubic via the intersection of the said parabola and hyperbola. This
cubic equation has only one real root which is
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
We can take the help of computer algebra to obtain the exact form of
this root as:

![\\tau=\\dfrac{1}{3}\\left(1+\\left(19-3\\sqrt{33}\\right)^{1/3}+\\left(19+3\\sqrt{33}\\right)^{1/3}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%3D%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D%5Cleft%281%2B%5Cleft%2819-3%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%5Cright%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%2B%5Cleft%2819%2B3%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%5Cright%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

The other two roots are complex conjugates:

![\\tau'=\\dfrac{1}{3} - \\dfrac{(19 - 3 \\sqrt{33})^{1/3}- (19 + 3
\\sqrt{33})^{1/3}}{6} + i\\dfrac{ \\sqrt{3}(19 - 3
\\sqrt{33})^{1/3}-\\sqrt{3}(19 + 3 \\sqrt{33})^{1/3}}{6}\\\\\[7pt\]
\\overline{\\tau'}=\\dfrac{1}{3} - \\dfrac{(19 - 3 \\sqrt{33})^{1/3}-
(19 + 3 \\sqrt{33})^{1/3}}{6} - i\\dfrac{ \\sqrt{3}(19 - 3
\\sqrt{33})^{1/3}-\\sqrt{3}(19 + 3
\\sqrt{33})^{1/3}}{6}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%27%3D%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D+-+%5Cdfrac%7B%2819+-+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D-+%2819+%2B+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%7D%7B6%7D+%2B+i%5Cdfrac%7B+%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%2819+-+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D-%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%2819+%2B+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%7D%7B6%7D%5C%5C%5B7pt%5D+%5Coverline%7B%5Ctau%27%7D%3D%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D+-+%5Cdfrac%7B%2819+-+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D-+%2819+%2B+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%7D%7B6%7D+-+i%5Cdfrac%7B+%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%2819+-+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D-%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%2819+%2B+3+%5Csqrt%7B33%7D%29%5E%7B1%2F3%7D%7D%7B6%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Comparable to the situation with
![\\phi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cphi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and its conjugate, these roots have a relationship of the form:

![\\tau=\\dfrac{1}{\\tau'
\\overline{\\tau'}}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%3D%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%27+%5Coverline%7B%5Ctau%27%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

There are also some other curious identities satisfied by
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
like:  
![\\dfrac{(1+\\tau)^2}{1+\\tau^2}=\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdfrac%7B%281%2B%5Ctau%29%5E2%7D%7B1%2B%5Ctau%5E2%7D%3D%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

**The convergent of Nārāyaṇa’s sequence and Mādhava’s
![\\arctan(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
series**  
The triple partitioning of a segment leads us to a geometric
construction that yields the relationship between
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
(Figure 3):

![\\pi=4\\left(\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau}\\right)+\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau^2}\\right)\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D4%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D%5Cright%29%2B%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D%5Cright%29%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Figure 3 provides a proof for this of a type the old Hindus termed the
upapatti or what in today’s mathematics is a proof without words (to our
knowledge never presented before). Nevertheless, for the geometrically
less-inclined we add a few words below to clarify this.

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig3.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribonacci_fig3.png)Figure
3

In Figure 3, one can see how
![\\angle{\\alpha}=\\arctan\\left(\\tfrac{1}{\\tau^2}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cangle%7B%5Calpha%7D%3D%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
It emerges once from the starting triply partitioned segment as
![\\angle{\\alpha}= \\arctan\\left (\\tfrac{\\tau}{\\tau^3}
\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cangle%7B%5Calpha%7D%3D+%5Carctan%5Cleft+%28%5Ctfrac%7B%5Ctau%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E3%7D+%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
The construction creates segments ![t_1, t_2,
t_3](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_1%2C+t_2%2C+t_3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
in the proportion of
![1:\\tau:\\tau^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%3A%5Ctau%3A%5Ctau%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus, we get the second occurrence of ![\\angle{\\alpha}=\\arctan\\left
(\\tfrac{t_1}{t_3}
\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cangle%7B%5Calpha%7D%3D%5Carctan%5Cleft+%28%5Ctfrac%7Bt_1%7D%7Bt_3%7D+%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
That in turn implies the occurrence of a vertical segment of size
![\\tau^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
From the construction we also get ![\\angle{\\beta}=\\arctan\\left
(\\tfrac{t_3}{t_1+t_2+t_3}\\right)=\\arctan\\left
(\\tfrac{1}{\\tau}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cangle%7B%5Cbeta%7D%3D%5Carctan%5Cleft+%28%5Ctfrac%7Bt_3%7D%7Bt_1%2Bt_2%2Bt_3%7D%5Cright%29%3D%5Carctan%5Cleft+%28%5Ctfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Thus,
![\\angle{\\alpha}+\\angle{\\beta}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cangle%7B%5Calpha%7D%2B%5Cangle%7B%5Cbeta%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
add up to form the congruent base angles of an isosceles right triangle
with congruent sides measuring
![\\tau+\\tau^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%2B%5Ctau%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
This implies that:

![\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau^2}\\right)+\\arctan\\left
(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau}\\right)= \\arctan(1)=\\dfrac{\\pi}{4}\\\\\[7pt\]
\\therefore
\\pi=4\\left(\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau}\\right)+\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau^2}\\right)\\right)
\\; \\; \\;
\_{...\\blacksquare}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D%5Cright%29%2B%5Carctan%5Cleft+%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D%5Cright%29%3D+%5Carctan%281%29%3D%5Cdfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B4%7D%5C%5C%5B7pt%5D+%5Ctherefore+%5Cpi%3D4%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D%5Cright%29%2B%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D%5Cright%29%5Cright%29+%5C%3B+%5C%3B+%5C%3B+_%7B...%5Cblacksquare%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Likewise we can also see that:

![\\pi=\\dfrac{4}{3}\\left(\\arctan(\\tau)+\\arctan\\left(\\tau^2\\right)\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdfrac%7B4%7D%7B3%7D%5Cleft%28%5Carctan%28%5Ctau%29%2B%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Ctau%5E2%5Cright%29%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Approximately contemporaneously with Nārāyaṇa’s work, apparently
unbeknownst to him, Mādhava, the great mathematician and astronomer from
Cerapada, presented his celebrated infinite series for the
![\\arctan(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
function:

![\\arctan(x)=\\dfrac{x}{1}-\\dfrac{x^3}{3}+\\dfrac{x^5}{5}-\\dfrac{x^7}{7}...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29%3D%5Cdfrac%7Bx%7D%7B1%7D-%5Cdfrac%7Bx%5E3%7D%7B3%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7Bx%5E5%7D%7B5%7D-%5Cdfrac%7Bx%5E7%7D%7B7%7D...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We can use the first of the above relationships between
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
and
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to obtain an infinite series for the former based on the latter:  
![\\pi=4\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau}-\\dfrac{1}{3\\tau^3}+\\dfrac{1}{5\\tau^5}-\\dfrac{1}{7\\tau^7}+\\dfrac{1}{9\\tau^9}-\\dfrac{1}{11\\tau^{11}}+\\dfrac{1}{13\\tau^{13}}...+\\dfrac{1}{\\tau^2}-\\dfrac{1}{3\\tau^6}+\\dfrac{1}{5\\tau^{10}}-\\dfrac{1}{7\\tau^{14}}...\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D4%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%5Ctau%5E3%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B5%5Ctau%5E5%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B7%5Ctau%5E7%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B9%5Ctau%5E9%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B11%5Ctau%5E%7B11%7D%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B13%5Ctau%5E%7B13%7D%7D...%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%5Ctau%5E6%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B5%5Ctau%5E%7B10%7D%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B7%5Ctau%5E%7B14%7D%7D...%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Gathering terms in order of their exponents we get:  
![\\pi=4\\left(\\dfrac{1}{\\tau}+\\dfrac{1}{\\tau^2}-\\dfrac{1}{3\\tau^3}+\\dfrac{1}{5\\tau^5}-\\dfrac{1}{3\\tau^6}-\\dfrac{1}{7\\tau^7}+\\dfrac{1}{9\\tau^9}+\\dfrac{1}{5\\tau^{10}}-\\dfrac{1}{11\\tau^{11}}+\\dfrac{1}{13\\tau^{13}}-\\dfrac{1}{7\\tau^{14}}...\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D4%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B%5Ctau%5E2%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%5Ctau%5E3%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B5%5Ctau%5E5%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%5Ctau%5E6%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B7%5Ctau%5E7%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B9%5Ctau%5E9%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B5%5Ctau%5E%7B10%7D%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B11%5Ctau%5E%7B11%7D%7D%2B%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B13%5Ctau%5E%7B13%7D%7D-%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B7%5Ctau%5E%7B14%7D%7D...%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

One notices that all except the fourth powers are represented. One can
compactly express this as:  
![\\pi=\\displaystyle 4\\sum\_{n=1}^{\\infty}
\\dfrac{a\[n\]}{n\\tau^n}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdisplaystyle+4%5Csum_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%7B%5Cinfty%7D+%5Cdfrac%7Ba%5Bn%5D%7D%7Bn%5Ctau%5En%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)  
Here the cyclic sequence
![a\[n\]](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
is defined thus:  
![a\[n\]=1, a\[n+1\]=2\\cdot (-1)^{m-1}, a\[n+2\]=-1, a\[n+3\]=0;
n=4(m-1)+1; m=1,2,3... a\[n\]=1, 2, -1, 0, 1, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, -1,
0...](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a%5Bn%5D%3D1%2C+a%5Bn%2B1%5D%3D2%5Ccdot+%28-1%29%5E%7Bm-1%7D%2C+a%5Bn%2B2%5D%3D-1%2C+a%5Bn%2B3%5D%3D0%3B+n%3D4%28m-1%29%2B1%3B+m%3D1%2C2%2C3...+a%5Bn%5D%3D1%2C+2%2C+-1%2C+0%2C+1%2C+-2%2C+-1%2C+0%2C+1%2C+2%2C+-1%2C+0...&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Using this series to calculate
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
results in reasonably fast convergence with a nearly linear increase in
the correct digits after the decimal point with every 4 terms. Thus,
with 200 terms we get
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
correct to 53 places after the decimal point (Figure 4). However, we
should keep in mind that
![n](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
actually includes a null term which removes every 4th powers; hence, the
real number of terms is lower by
![\\tfrac{n}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7Bn%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribo_pi.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_tribo_pi.png)Figure
4

Using just the first 3 terms we get an approximation of
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that works as well as
![\\tfrac{22}{7}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctfrac%7B22%7D%7B7%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as:

![\\pi \\approx 4
\\left(\\dfrac{3\\tau^2+3\\tau-1}{3\\tau^2+3\\tau+3}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+%5Capprox+4+%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B3%5Ctau%5E2%2B3%5Ctau-1%7D%7B3%5Ctau%5E2%2B3%5Ctau%2B3%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

We can further compare this to the famous single angle
![\\arctan](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
infinite series for
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
provided by Mādhava using bhūta-saṃkhya (the Hindu numerical code):

vyāse vāridhi-nihate rūpa-hṛte vyāsa-sāgarābhihate \|  
tri-śarādi-viṣama-saṃkhyā-bhaktaṃ ṛṇaṃ svaṃ pṛthak kramāt kuryāt \|\|  
In the diameter multiplied by the oceans (4) and divided by the form
(1), subtraction and addition \[of terms\] should be repeatedly done of
the diameter multiplied by the oceans (4) and divided respectively by 3,
the arrows (5) and so on of odd numbers.

In modern notation that would be:

![\\pi=\\displaystyle 4\\sum\_{n=1}^{\\infty}
\\dfrac{1}{2n-1}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdisplaystyle+4%5Csum_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%7B%5Cinfty%7D+%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B2n-1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

[![](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_pi_madhava.png)](https://manasataramgini.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/narayana_pi_madhava.png)Figure
5

This series converges very slowly and in an oscillatory fashion (Figure
5) reaching just 2 correct digits after the decimal point after
computing 200 terms. The oscillatory convergence features an alternation
of better and worse approximations, with the latter showing a curious
feature. For example, with 25 terms we encounter 3.1*8*15 which is
“correct” up to 4 places after the point (3.1415) except for the wrong 8
in the second place. With 50 terms we get 3.1*2*159465, which is correct
to 8 places (3.14159465) after the point except for the wrong 2 at the
second place. More such instances can be found as we go along the
expansion. For example at 500 terms we get:  
3.141592653589793238  
3.1*39*59265*5*5897*8*3238

This is correct to 18 places except for 4 wrong places. Late J. Borwein
and colleagues have reported an occurrence of this phenomenon even in a
calculation of ![5 \\times
10^6](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=5+%5Ctimes+10%5E6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
terms of this series.

Thus, the double angle series based on
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
fares way better than the basic single angle Mādhava series for
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
Of course, Mādhava was well aware that it converged very slowly. Hence,
he and others in his school like the Nampūtiri-s, the great Nilakaṇṭha
Somayājin, Jyeṣṭadeva and Citrabhānu, devised some terminal correction
terms to derive alternative series to speed up convergence and obtained
approximations of
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
that had good accuracy for those times. Two of their series which were
mediocre in convergence speed are in modern notation:

![\\pi=\\displaystyle 4\\left(\\dfrac{3}{4}+\\sum\_{n=1}^\\infty
\\dfrac{-1^{n+1}}{(2n+1)^3-(2n+1)}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdisplaystyle+4%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B3%7D%7B4%7D%2B%5Csum_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%5Cinfty+%5Cdfrac%7B-1%5E%7Bn%2B1%7D%7D%7B%282n%2B1%29%5E3-%282n%2B1%29%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This sequence produces ![\\pi \\approx
3.1415926](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+%5Capprox+3.1415926&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
after 200 terms.

![\\pi=\\displaystyle\\sum\_{n=1}^\\infty \\dfrac{-1^{n+1} \\cdot
16}{(2n-1)^5+4(2n-1)}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdisplaystyle%5Csum_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%5Cinfty+%5Cdfrac%7B-1%5E%7Bn%2B1%7D+%5Ccdot+16%7D%7B%282n-1%29%5E5%2B4%282n-1%29%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This one works better than the above and produces ![\\pi \\approx
3.141592653589](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+%5Capprox+3.141592653589&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
after 200 terms

The third uses
![\\tan\\left(\\tfrac{\\pi}{3}\\right)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctan%5Cleft%28%5Ctfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B3%7D%5Cright%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
as a multiplicand:

![\\pi=\\displaystyle\\sum\_{n=1}^\\infty \\dfrac{-1^{x-1}\\cdot
2\\sqrt{3}}{3^{n-1}(2n-1)}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi%3D%5Cdisplaystyle%5Csum_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%5Cinfty+%5Cdfrac%7B-1%5E%7Bx-1%7D%5Ccdot+2%5Csqrt%7B3%7D%7D%7B3%5E%7Bn-1%7D%282n-1%29%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

This series fares much better and produces 97 correct digits after the
decimal point with 200 terms. This is quite impressive because it
outdoes the above double angle series based on ![\\tau,
\\tau^2](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau%2C+%5Ctau%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
It is quite likely that Mādhava and Citrabhānu used this series for
around 20-25 terms to obtain approximations such as the below (expressed
in bhūta-saṃkhya):

vibudha-netra-gajāhi-hutāśana-triguṇa-veda-bha-vāraṇa-bāhavaḥ \|  
nava-nikharva-mite vṛtti-vistare paridhimānam idaṃ jagadur budhāḥ \|\|  
The gods (33), eyes (2), elephants (8), snakes (8), the fires thrice
(333), the veda-s (4), the asterisms (27), the elephants (8), the hands
(2) is the measure of the circumference of a circle with diameter of ![9
\\times 10^{11}
](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=9+%5Ctimes+10%5E%7B11%7D+&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002),
so had stated the mathematicians:

![\\pi \\approx \\dfrac{2827433388233}{900000000000} \\approx
3.14159265359](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+%5Capprox+%5Cdfrac%7B2827433388233%7D%7B900000000000%7D+%5Capprox+3.14159265359&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

In addition to approximations of
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
derived from studies on
![\\arctan(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
series we also see that Mādhava’s successors, if not himself, were also
using a sequence of continued fraction convergents of
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002).
These were probably inspired by the ability to initially calculate good
approximations using series derived from the
![\\arctan(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
series such as the above. Of these a large one is explicitly stated by
Śankara-vāriyar and Nārāyaṇa Nampūtiri in their work the Kriyākramakarī:

vṛtta-vyāse hate nāga-veda-vahny-abdhi-khendubhiḥ \|  
tithy-aśvi-vibudhair bhakte susūkṣmaḥ paridhir bhavet \|\|  
Multiplying the diameter of a circle by snakes(8), veda-s(4), the fires
(3), the oceans (4), the space (0), the moon (1) and dividing it by the
tithi-s (15), Aśvin-s (2), gods (33) one may get the circumference to
good accuracy.

![\\pi \\approx \\dfrac{104348}{33215} \\approx
3.141592653](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi+%5Capprox+%5Cdfrac%7B104348%7D%7B33215%7D+%5Capprox+3.141592653&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

The
![\\arctan(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
sequence remained a workhorse for calculating
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
long after the heroics of Mādhava’s school. A particularly famous double
angle formula was obtained by Euler with a [simple geometric
proof](https://manasataramgini.wordpress.com/2017/04/20/eulers-squares/):

![\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{2}\\right)+\\arctan\\left(\\dfrac{1}{3}\\right)=\\dfrac{\\pi}{4}](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B2%7D%5Cright%29%2B%5Carctan%5Cleft%28%5Cdfrac%7B1%7D%7B3%7D%5Cright%29%3D%5Cdfrac%7B%5Cpi%7D%7B4%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)

Using this formula we get we get a rather good convergence and reach 122
correct places after the decimal point with 200 terms.

**Tailpiece: From
![\\phi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cphi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
to
![\\pi](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cpi&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
via
![\\arcsin(x)](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Carcsin%28x%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)**  
We may conclude by noting that the while
![\\tau](https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctau&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0&c=20201002)
